headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Corporation Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the confere
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Corporation Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Abigail, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to
componenttext:
Thank you, Abigail, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.40 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7 -- $7.81 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $764 million. Incidentally, we
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.40 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7 -- $7.81 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $764 million. Incidentally, we beat analyst consensus by $0.02, which is hard to do this late new year.
Revenue and operating earnings were down against the year-ago quarter by 6.6% and 2.9%, respectively. Earnings from continuing operations, however, were up $27 million on the strength of a 50 basis point improvement in operating margin and a lower tax rate.
Similarly, earnings and diluted share from continuing operations were up $0.21, almost 10%. By the way, in connection with the comparisons to the year-ago quarter, let's remember that the fourth quarter 2014 was and remains the strongest revenue performance of any quarter in the last 4 years and by no small measure. So it is a very difficult comparison, and that will be true in the business segments as well.
Sequentially, the quarters are very similar. Revenue was down $185 million or 2.3%, but operating earnings were up $2 million on [ph] a 40 basis point improvement in margin rate. So all in all, a solid quarter with particularly good performance in the Aerospace group, which I'll speak about a little bit more detail.
So for the year, where does that leave us? We had fully diluted earnings per share of $9.08 on revenue of $31.47 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $2.97 billion. Return on sales was 9.4%. Revenue for the year was up $617 million or 2%. Operating earnings were up $289 million or 7.4% on a 70 basis point improvement in operating margin.
Earnings from continuing operations were up $292 million or 10.9%, helped by a 200 basis point improvement in the effective tax rate. This, together with share repurchases activity, led quite naturally to a 16% improvement in earnings per share. So all in all, 2015 was a great year, improving significantly over a very good 2014. It was a year of further progress from an operating perspective and revenue growth consistent with our guidance to you at this time last year.
Turning to cash. Free cash flow from operations was $120 million in the quarter. For the year, we had free cash flow from operations of $1.93 billion, which is 65% of earnings from continuing operations. As we advised you at the beginning of the year, free cash flow from operations was not going to reach 100% of net earnings for 3 reasons: First, we are working of a very large advance payment received in 2014 on a major Combat Systems program. Second, we have an increase in operating working capital at Gulfstream, consistent with building numerous aircraft for task and fleet reduction parts in connection with the G500 and 600 program. And third, we were also working off large advance payments received in 2014 at NASSCO for commercial shipbuilding programs. All of this will normalize and unwind quite positively, but not until 2017. In 2016, we will continue to have less than our usual robust free cash flow.
Let me give you some color on the quarter and year in each of the business groups. First, Aerospace. Revenue was down modestly over the year-ago quarter. Sales were down $98 million, but earnings were down just $2 million as a result of a 70 basis point improvement in margin, very nice operating performance.
For the year, revenue was $8.85 billion, and operating earnings were $1.71 billion with an operating margin of 19.3%. This is a year-over-year improvement of 2.3% on sale, 5.9% on earnings and 70 basis points on operating margin. All in all, a very good year at Aerospace with strong operating leverage and good order intake.
During the quarter, we took down the production rate of the G550 to what would be the sustaining rate through 2016. The G450 will come down modestly in the first quarter of 2016. By the same token, the production rate of the G650 and 650ER were taken up during the second half of 2014 and will be taken up again in 2016 to reflect current demand and our sizable backlog. The production rate on the G650 and 650ER is clearly sustainable for this year and next.
So contrary to what many investors seem to have anticipated, order activity in the quarter was quite good. The book-to-bill at Gulfstream was at least 1:1; both dollar base, 1:1; and in unit of green delivery, 1.1:1, with particularly strong demand for the G650 and 650ER. By the way, an interesting data point. As if there were more orders for in-production aircraft in 2015 than 2014. All in all, the order activity going into the first quarter of this year is quite good.
Let me say a few words about the large cabin business jet market in general. We find demand to be reasonable. We see no evidence at Gulfstream of a cyclical decline. The order activity is good but not frenetic, and North America is particularly good. More than 50% of our orders for the year were from North America. I shall also point out that despite the handling by some, our orders from Asia Pacific improved by more than 60% over 2014. In short, this market is not a bullion, but it is steady from our perspective. We also seem to be picking up some share from other OEM.
Combat Systems. At combat, revenue was down $90 million or 5.6%, and earnings were down $37 million or 13.7% on a 140 basis point reduction in operating margin over the year-ago quarter. Nevertheless, a 15 4% operating margin was more than respectable and consistent with our expectations for the group.
Sequentially, the story begins to foretell the future. Sales were up $179 million and earnings were up $16 million. That is 13.3% and 7.3%, respectively. For the full year, sales were down $92 million or 1.6%, and earnings were up $20 million or 2.3% on a 60 basis point improvement in operating margin. This margin expansion is the result of restructuring at both our European and accordance and tactical systems businesses. By the way, this performance is reasonably consistent with the guidance we provided at this time last year. You may recall that we had guided to flat revenue and earnings. Overall, Combat Systems was a story of revenue reasonably consistent with expectations and outstanding costs and margin performance.
By the way, in just a moment Jason's going to give you a little bit more color on this group's revenue performance.
This is a business poised for a modest growth in 2016 and quite significant growth in the 2017 through '19 timeframe, as we begin delivering on our $19 billion backlog.
Now Marine systems. The group's revenue of $1.98 billion in the quarter was down $58 million or 2.8% compared to the year-ago quarter and down $105 million or 5%, sequentially. Revenue for the year, however, was up $701 million, a rather extraordinary 9.6%. And recall that this increase in annual revenue follows the $600 million increase in 2014.
Operating earnings were down $21 million or 10.9% against the year-ago quarter and down $9 million or 5% sequentially. For the full year, earnings were up $25 million or 3.6%, in spite of 50 basis point decline in operating margin.
In the Marine group, we guided you at this time last year to revenue growth of 2% to 2.5%, which we exceeded by a fair measure. We forecast margins at 9.5% and round [ph] up at 9.1%. So the story here was better-than-anticipated revenue but not as good as expected operating margin, which left us relatively consistent with our guidance for operating earnings.
The growth in revenue in the year was driven by electric growth [ph] on 2 Virginia class construction -- 2 Virginia-class submarine construction and increased engineering work for the Ohio replacement program. This group's margin's at a result of a mixed shift. Ohio engineering work, transitioning to Block IV from Block III and increased work on commercial jobs at ships at NASSCO.
IS&T is a business group where, once again, we saw less-than-expected revenue decline, coupled with improved operating performance. Several of our major ground in maritime programs were all funded beyond our plan, improving our sales performance. Margin improvement was a result of greater efficiencies and plans and business unit consolidation and continuing operating performance across all the portfolio.
Revenue in the quarter was $2.16 billion, down $307 billion or 12.4% against the year-ago quarter, a very difficult compared or as I have mentioned previously. On the other hand, operating earnings of $230 million in the quarter or 8.5% better than the fourth quarter a year ago. On a sequential basis, operating earnings were up $11 million or 5% on a strength of 10.6% margin, 70 basis points better than last quarter.
For the year, revenue was down $194 million or only 2.1%. Remember, this is dramatically less than the 5.5% revenue decline we forecasted in our guidance to you at this time last year. For the year, earnings were up $118 million or 15%, very good operating performance in the face of a 2% revenue decline.
On this call a year ago, I gave you guidance with respect to operating margins in this -- in the 9% range, which we beat by 110 basis points. All in all, we beat forecasted revenue and operating margins. When that happens, the result is significant upside to the forecast.
On this call a year ago, on a company-wide basis, our guidance for 2015 was to expect revenue of $31.3 billion to $31.5 billion, an operating margin rate of 12.8%, a tax rate of 30.5% and a return on sales of 8.7%. We wound up the year with revenue at $31.47 billion and operating margin rate of 13.3%, an effective tax rate of 27.7% and a return on sales of 9.4%.
Last year at this time, we provided EPS guidance of $8.05 to $8.10. We round up at $9.08. About 46% of the improvement came from better-than-planned operating performance: $0.05 from the gain on the sale of a small business, $0.30 from a lower-than-planned tax rate and the balance from a lower share count as a result of share repurchases. Certainly, a great year by any measure.
So let me provide some thoughts about 2016, initially by group and then on a company-wide rollout. In Aerospace, we expect revenue to be approximately $8.9 billion, up very modestly; margin rate should be down 10 to 20 basis points; and operating earnings flat to last year; 2017 should look a lot like 2016, with upside in revenue and earnings if we can deliver G500 in the fourth quarter; revenue and earnings growth will resume with full scale production and delivery of the G500 and 218 and the G600 the following year. In Combat, we expect revenue to be up $160 million and the margin rates similar to 2015, with more rigorous growth of both revenue and earnings in 2017, 2018 and '19. The Marine group is expected to have revenues similar to 2015, but improved operating earnings as a result of operating margins in the mid-9% range.
Revenue in 2017 and 2018 will have growth of a couple of hundred million a year and additional $0.5 billion in 2019 growth. 
Finally, in IS&T, we expect a modest improvement in revenue and a 20 to 30 basis point decline in operating margin. Let me remind you again that a gain on the sale of a business was included in 2015 operating earnings and margin rate. This will result in essentially flat operating earnings year-over-year. Once again, we should see more solid revenue growth in 2017 and '18.
All of this rolls up to $31.6 billion to $31.8 billion of revenue, operating margin around 13.3% and return on sales of roughly 9.1%.
Let me emphasize that this plan is purely from operation. It assumes a 29.5% tax rate, assumed -- and assumes we buy only enough shares to hold the share count steady with year-end figures so as to avoid dilution from auction exercise. This rolls up to an EPS guidance of around $9.20 per fully diluted share. This compares with last year's guidance of $8.05 to $8.10 at the same time on the same basis.
Let me also reconcile this forecast in 9 22, our 2015 year-end resulted 9 08. In 2016, we will not have the operating gain from the sale of the business. That gain was $0.05 of EPS. In 2016, we will have higher interest expense with a $0.02 negative impact to 2016 EPS. We will also have a higher effective tax rate in 2016 that will cost us $0.23 per share.
Foreign exchange headwinds at current FX rates will cost another $0.04 of EPS compared to 2015. On a pro forma basis, this adjusts 2015 to 8 74, and gives us a 5% adjusted growth in forecasted 2016 EPS before deployment of capital.
With respect to the quarterly progression for EPS, it looks like most years. So divide our guidance by 4 and take $0.20 off of Q1, $0.10 off Q2, a Q3 even and about 40 -- $0.30 up in Q4. So much like last year, beating our guidance must come from outperforming the operating plan and the effect of capital deployment.
With respect to deployment of capital, we anticipate using all of our free cash flow in 2016 for dividends and share repurchase. While we don't anticipate a robust year from a free cash flow perspective for the reasons I have previously described, we will use balance sheet cash to some degree to supplement our free cash flow for share repurchase activity. I have more to say on the subject at the end of the first quarter, as our planning becomes more refined and is approved by our board.
I'd now like to turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. As we discussed previously, we felt more of an impact in our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility in 2015 than we have in the past. In particular, this issue has had a negative impact on our growth ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. As we discussed previously, we felt more of an impact in our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility in 2015 than we have in the past. In particular, this issue has had a negative impact on our growth experience in our Combat Systems group given their increasing international activity.
As Phebe pointed out, the group's full year revenue was down 1.6% compared to 2014. But in foreign exchange rates, particularly the U.S. dollar to the euro and to the Canadian dollar, held constant from 2014 to this year, the group's sales would have actually increased by 6.4% in 2015.
For the company as a whole, this would have taken our 2% top line growth over 2014 to almost 4%. As a reminder, this had nothing to do with any economic exposure or losses. This is merely the translation of our various international indigenous businesses into U.S. dollars for consolidated reporting purposes and the negative effect on that translation that comes with a strengthening dollar.
Given what we see the mix of Combat Systems programs in the years ahead, we expect foreign currency fluctuation to be an ongoing part of the group's story.
Net interest expense in the quarter was $19 million, consistent with the fourth quarter of 2014. For the year, interest expense was $83 million, $3 million less than a year before due to the repayment of $500 million of fixed rate notes that occurred in 2015. For 2016, we expect net interest expense of around $95 million, and the increase is due primarily to less interest income as we deployed cash off the balance sheet.
As we deploy that cash over the year, we'd moved from a net cash position of cash in excess of debt of $1 billion at the end of 2014 to a net debt position of $614 million, and I'll walk through those capital deployment activity in just a moment.
Our effective tax rate was 27.7% for the year, right in the ballpark and slightly lower than the 28% we forecasted at the end of the third quarter. The lower outcome is attributable to favorable contract closeouts with the IRS and Congress' enactment of tax extender [indiscernible] late December. In particular, the research and experimentation credit. For the year, the research tax credit extension benefited our rate by about 50 basis points, but was offset by some onetime unfavorable effects of other provisions in the extended law. The combined effect was a 20 basis point reduction in the 2015 effective rate or about $0.02 per share.
You may recall at this time last year that given our increasing international presence, we considered the new normal for our effective tax rate to be in the 30% to 30.5% range.
For 2016, with the research tax credit now permanent, we expect an effective tax rate in the mid-29% range.
Moving on to our pension plans. We contributed about $185 million to our pension plans in 2015 as forecasts. And for 2016, we expect that amount to be approximately $200 million, to be contributed mostly during the third quarter.
And finally, on the capital deployment front. To summarize our activities for the year, we spent approximately $3.2 billion on share repurchases. And when you combine the share repurchases with our dividend payments, we used $4.1 billion in shareholder friendly actions in 2015 or 2.1x our free cash flow from operations for the year.
Erin, that concludes my remarks. And I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Peter Arment with Sterne Agee.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe this is a good opportunity just because we haven't spoke since the budget deal. Maybe you can kind of give us get of your overview, how you see that impacting domestically. And also related to that, are you seeing any changes on the internati
componenttext: Phebe, maybe this is a good opportunity just because we haven't spoke since the budget deal. Maybe you can kind of give us get of your overview, how you see that impacting domestically. And also related to that, are you seeing any changes on the international order front just given what has happened with the world prices to one of your customers?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the budget deal provided us funding in line with -- exactly in line with what we anticipated. So no surprises there and some of side frankly in a couple of various. That stability is critical and very helpful as we think through the defense portfolio f
componenttext: So the budget deal provided us funding in line with -- exactly in line with what we anticipated. So no surprises there and some of side frankly in a couple of various. That stability is critical and very helpful as we think through the defense portfolio for the next year or 2. So that was I think very helpful. But as I said, it was consistent with what we had anticipated. With respect to international orders, we have continued to increase, and particularly on the Combat Systems side, increased our order activity internationally. And so far, we have yet to see any impact from oil prices in the Mid East. As we talked a lot in the past from our perspective, that spending is completely determined by the threat. And the threat environment in that world has gotten nothing but worst.  So we're very sensitive to our customers' needs and requirements and we work carefully with them pressure that we can provide them what they need when they wanted it in terms that are favorable to us and which they can accommodate. I would also remind you, by the way, that most of our orders in that part of the world are government to government, which provides some stability. So that is a benefit to us as well as we look forward.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You'd talked a little bit about free cash flow not being that robust this year and you had talked about last -- I guess, in 2015, with the Aerospace investments. Can you just walk through what kind of expectations? And then what changes as a going to 2017
componenttext: You'd talked a little bit about free cash flow not being that robust this year and you had talked about last -- I guess, in 2015, with the Aerospace investments. Can you just walk through what kind of expectations? And then what changes as a going to 2017 that makes it start to see it return to 100% conversion?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's all 3 -- it's a reversal and lining of all 3 of the factors that we talked about impacted 2015 and '16, but let's take Gulfstream. We're continuing to build demonstration and test aircraft for both the 500 and 600. Our capital deployment, our C
componenttext: Well, it's all 3 -- it's a reversal and lining of all 3 of the factors that we talked about impacted 2015 and '16, but let's take Gulfstream. We're continuing to build demonstration and test aircraft for both the 500 and 600. Our capital deployment, our CapEx is largely done at Gulfstream, but that build up in inventory will continue until we begin to take or deliver the G500 and G600. So that will help unwind that buildup of working capital at Gulfstream. NASSCO will have it completed its Jones Act ship in '17, and we anticipate a number of orders coming into the Marine group that, of course, [indiscernible] cash. And Combat Systems, we will begin to get additional cash as we ramp-up until full rate production on a number of our international quarters. So 2015, '16, lighter than were normal -- than were used to. But 2017 will be above, if every expectation we have is that will above 100% of net income.

componenttextpreview: Phebe, on Gulfstream, can you just talk about what you're expecting actually from -- the actual number of large cabin deliveries you're expecting in '16? And then can you talk about what the reducing rate on the 450 and 550? What that's done to shrink or
componenttext: Phebe, on Gulfstream, can you just talk about what you're expecting actually from -- the actual number of large cabin deliveries you're expecting in '16? And then can you talk about what the reducing rate on the 450 and 550? What that's done to shrink or to expand the lead time?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me take those into sort of we've been reducing the 450 very, in fact, immateriality for the last 7 or 8 quarters. So in line again with what we saw in demand and what we predicted in demand. And as to be expected, we reduces -- reduced the G550 pro
componenttext: So let me take those into sort of we've been reducing the 450 very, in fact, immateriality for the last 7 or 8 quarters. So in line again with what we saw in demand and what we predicted in demand. And as to be expected, we reduces -- reduced the G550 production rate in the fourth quarter, again in line with demand. Our wait times are essentially the same, 3 to 4 quarters in those lines of business. In 2016, you asked about what are our production and delivery -- what are our delivery targets and plan. Large cabin, about 104; medium cabin, 34. That compares to 2015. Large cabin is 112 and medium cabin of about -- mid cabin, about 35. So down 8 large and 1 medium cabin with a better mix I might add. And that's what you would expect the better mix at the end [ph] of this year of transition. More 650s, 450s and 550s.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask for a follow on to David's question just on the pricing environment and then I have a more technical question on your share authorization. Last year, you did this twice. And you had one in December. You mentioned there might be something c
componenttext: I wanted to ask for a follow on to David's question just on the pricing environment and then I have a more technical question on your share authorization. Last year, you did this twice. And you had one in December. You mentioned there might be something coming at the end of Q1. Is twice the norm going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about the pricing environment. We have held our prices very consistently. In to the extent that others are having pricing pressure, it hasn't affected us immateriality. So I think that's full and short answer to that question, Jason.
componenttext: Let me talk about the pricing environment. We have held our prices very consistently. In to the extent that others are having pricing pressure, it hasn't affected us immateriality. So I think that's full and short answer to that question, Jason.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the shares repurchase authorization, so you're right, we did a total of $20 million authorized last year in 2 tranches. We've got $10 million authorized late in the year by the board. Certainly, wouldn't want to get ahead of them in terms of
componenttext: Yes, I think the shares repurchase authorization, so you're right, we did a total of $20 million authorized last year in 2 tranches. We've got $10 million authorized late in the year by the board. Certainly, wouldn't want to get ahead of them in terms of the plans for the coming year, but we'll address that as it comes and as the opportunistic approach to share repurchases works than that current authorization, we'll kind of see where it goes midway through the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, the usual question I'll ask we go through. I mean, you had much better Gulfstream margin in the fourth quarter than the third, even though the revenues were down. Maybe you can explain a little more what happened there. And then going forward with
componenttext: Phebe, the usual question I'll ask we go through. I mean, you had much better Gulfstream margin in the fourth quarter than the third, even though the revenues were down. Maybe you can explain a little more what happened there. And then going forward with 650s being up, I would think they probably had the highest margin at this point. So why would the margin deteriorate a little bit in '16?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me talk about revenue. We -- as we noted before, we reduced the G50 to 550 rate for the fourth quarter. We had less preowned revenues than anticipated and somewhat less-than-anticipated service revenue. But Gulfstream was up and their backlog was u
componenttext: So let me talk about revenue. We -- as we noted before, we reduced the G50 to 550 rate for the fourth quarter. We had less preowned revenues than anticipated and somewhat less-than-anticipated service revenue. But Gulfstream was up and their backlog was up. Jet was down 5% in revenue, and that was mixed-driven as we increased our engineering work in anticipation of the production work that we're starting this year. And we had lower FPO revenue because of fuel prices. We also had reduced business jet completions in St. Louis. So that sort of ties the bow on revenue. In margins, it's the same old stuff we always get, right? We had some of the usual suspects. So we had mixed shift. We had liquidated damages, launched systems. And by the way, you' quite rightly pointed out. We had improved margins in the 650. So we anticipate roughly comparable margins. Those are what we -- we'll get leading you to, guiding you to is -- are not sufficient or significant material degradations in the margin rate. But what we are focused on and have been laser-focused on and have been telling our investors for some time, we are going to keep earnings flat. And that's why we signed up for nd we see the path forward to clearly do that.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On IS&T, Phebe, about a year ago or so, I think you were set a very pleasantly surprised at how well IS&T is holding up. I mean, it has held up quite well. Others in similar businesses has a lot of issues. But that closed down a little bit in this quarter
componenttext: On IS&T, Phebe, about a year ago or so, I think you were set a very pleasantly surprised at how well IS&T is holding up. I mean, it has held up quite well. Others in similar businesses has a lot of issues. But that closed down a little bit in this quarter. If you look inside that business and look forward and you separate into Mission Systems and GDIT, how do you see those 2 outlooks going now over the next couple of years?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me talk a little bit about the book-to-bill. With the exception of the fourth quarter, the 2014, '15, our IS&T book-to-bill has been approximately 1:1 every other quarter in both years. Q4, in those lines of businesses, tends to be more of an is
componenttext: Okay. Let me talk a little bit about the book-to-bill. With the exception of the fourth quarter, the 2014, '15, our IS&T book-to-bill has been approximately 1:1 every other quarter in both years. Q4, in those lines of businesses, tends to be more of an issue, timing issue than anything else. And we expect book-to-bill for 2016 about 1:1. These are businesses that are performing extremely well and winning more than their fair share based on their ability to increase their operating leverage by decreasing costs and are performance has been outstanding. So it's more of the same for them going forward. So we'll put dedication to cost-cutting, operating performance, much perform on backlog. And that's quite nicely needs to the kinds of book-to-bill that we've seen in these businesses. So I see that as working us to come.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you see Mission Systems and GDIT behaving somewhat differently? They have somewhat different drivers.
componenttext: Do you see Mission Systems and GDIT behaving somewhat differently? They have somewhat different drivers.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they're different margin businesses. Mission systems tend to be more heavily product oriented in nature and products tend to carry higher margins. Our IT businesses services, services have lower margins. But I'd like to tell everybody they got great
componenttext: Well, they're different margin businesses. Mission systems tend to be more heavily product oriented in nature and products tend to carry higher margins. Our IT businesses services, services have lower margins. But I'd like to tell everybody they got great cash performance. In fact, by the way, both of those businesses have a great cash performance. And with our services business, terrific return on invested capital for there's no invested capital. Think about our information, our IT services businesses, when they go-to-market, they go-to-market in their core, and they are very competitive in their core, both through past performance and cost competitiveness. So I like where they're positioned, and that hasn't changed for us. They continue to in and they're a big dog in the barnyard. Too many metaphors.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on Gulfstream for a second and on the 650 in particular. There's -- could you comment on where the skyline currently reaches to? And also a little bit on the preowned or, I guess, the available for sale 650s that are on the market? A
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on Gulfstream for a second and on the 650 in particular. There's -- could you comment on where the skyline currently reaches to? And also a little bit on the preowned or, I guess, the available for sale 650s that are on the market? At kind of -- at what point do you see that as being more of a threat to production? Is it always going to be a battle of if the light news starts to approach price points of your [indiscernible] come off the line?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me answer that in the inverse order. We have seen and don't anticipate seeing any impact from the planes that are in the used market. It really hasn't impacted us at all because the guidance of the demand for that airplane has been. And we believe we
componenttext: Let me answer that in the inverse order. We have seen and don't anticipate seeing any impact from the planes that are in the used market. It really hasn't impacted us at all because the guidance of the demand for that airplane has been. And we believe we will continue to be very, very wholesome. Despite taking up our production rate slightly, we are still at first quarter '18 first available. So that tells you, that is a strong sustainable backlog for a very powerful airplane.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to turn to Marine for a moment, Phebe. There's a number of dynamics going on there. You've been -- you have a new agreement in path. You've got a couple of new opportunities. And then at the same time, you've been working through the Jones Act back
componenttext: I want to turn to Marine for a moment, Phebe. There's a number of dynamics going on there. You've been -- you have a new agreement in path. You've got a couple of new opportunities. And then at the same time, you've been working through the Jones Act backlog. Could you describe a little bit of the working parts there? And what might the Navy also do in terms of service going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, let me talk about all 3 of those businesses and give you a little bit of color. We have achieved a very significant agreement with our partners, our workforce in Maine and that it will allow gas to be increasingly competitive going forward in all
componenttext: So yes, let me talk about all 3 of those businesses and give you a little bit of color. We have achieved a very significant agreement with our partners, our workforce in Maine and that it will allow gas to be increasingly competitive going forward in all its competitions. And we're very proud of our workforce there, and we are very optimistic about our ability to compete on a going-forward basis. So I like what I see at that. And by the way, it was announced on the DDG 1000, the first one is 98% done, so we'll move out the door. Second one, 845 done. And again, with the kinds of issues that you might expect on first-of-class ships, but nothing that has been particularly surprising to us. The third ship I think is only about 40% done, but it has a deck house that we internally designed and built. So that reduces the risk going forward. So I see the future for that very nice. At NASSCO, we are continuing to work off the backlog of act ship isn't quite ready to point out. There is we believe significant demand going forward because of the age of the fleet that has to be replaced for more Jones Act ships. Our experience in the Jones Act market is it's highly lumpy. And -- but there is demand out there because of NASSCO's performance and because of its good cost structure. They have been very competitive in there and Jones Act competitions and won a nice backlog. And we continue that -- we continue to believe we'll add to that backlog. Their service businesses been performing very, very nicely. The Navy is what we believe quite rightly moving to fixed price service contracts, and we know how to work less and we've been very closely with the Navy customers. So we like what we see in service, particularly out West in San Diego. A little bit of lightness in Norfolk area as the Navy. We  [indiscernible] some of it some comforting of a major ship. But we anticipate service ships grow reasonably well on the surface ship side. Single digit, lower single digit with nice operating performance. We also anticipate additional Marine service at electrical. Nothing to significant, but again right in our sweet spot. And again, at electrical [indiscernible] so Virginia and Ohio, right? So I think 1 sliver of that kind of portfolio.

And as you think about margins there, obviously you talked about the margins being up as part of the vigorous earnings growth in combat. But when you look at potential for margins and defense businesses in aggregate and mainly IS&T and Marine, what's the outlook for those similar to the comments you made for combat?

componenttext: Sure. And Carter, if I understand, you're talking about this sort of the walk forward on EPS from '15 to '16. And really, when you think about our pension, our pension plan and our accounting for those plans, especially in the defense businesses, that it's a muted effect on EPS. So it really just to the commercial potential side, which had a negligible effect. I haven't calculated it, but it's nothing to be.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let's talk about the businesses. On a going forward basis, we anticipate the IS&T group to be at around a 10% margin business. That may vary from quarter to quarter or year to year, depending on how much revenue the service business brings in. But for
componenttext: So let's talk about the businesses. On a going forward basis, we anticipate the IS&T group to be at around a 10% margin business. That may vary from quarter to quarter or year to year, depending on how much revenue the service business brings in. But for our foreseeable future, that's about a 10% business. Combat, we see in the mid-15, 15 5, pretty steady, Eddie. So we may have -- and we do I believe, have margin expansion opportunities at the platform businesses. But remember, that will be somewhat offset by the short-cycle business of OTF, which we had terrific margins out of that business after we consolidated 2 units in 2014. With all things at defense, some of that business need to go back to our customer quite appropriately so. So that will cause some margin compression for them. But right there, what we're planning for combat steady-state of 15%, 15.5% margin, we will of course strive for higher. And then the Marine group will be a 9.5% to 10% margin business depending on mix. as we've talked about before. Performance at shipyard is all -- well performing shipyard is all about the mix, and we've got a number of mixed shift issues, which we've kind of articulated. So I think that gives you a sense of how we see our business going forward.

componenttext: So at Gulfstream I guess, 2 issues. One is if could give us any help in terms of where the R&D and launch is in your plan for '16? And secondly, I guess, more importantly, you had a 7% layoff you announced in December. Maybe walk us through if there's any severance impact in the fourth quarter and the types of benefit you expect to realize from that in 2016?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk a little bit about the reduction and then I'll turn it over to David. We've been talking for the last year or so about the transition period moving from the 450, 550 to 500 and 600. We're in it now. And quite appropriately, you would expect us
componenttext: Let me talk a little bit about the reduction and then I'll turn it over to David. We've been talking for the last year or so about the transition period moving from the 450, 550 to 500 and 600. We're in it now. And quite appropriately, you would expect us to fight for that. So our headcount reductions were all about sizing appropriately for what we see in terms of revenue. And our promise to keep margins -- well, keep earnings flat year-over-year. So we did some pruning. Headcount reductions were just a part of our cost-cutting efforts as we've improved our operating performance. Took a fair amount of overhead out and touch labor and we'll continue to do so on a going forward basis.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the R&D question, as you can imagine, the pace of that will sort of follow the cadence of the flight test program. So we expect that to pick up modestly in the next year and a little bit more in '17 as we continue through the program. But I say mode
componenttext: So on the R&D question, as you can imagine, the pace of that will sort of follow the cadence of the flight test program. So we expect that to pick up modestly in the next year and a little bit more in '17 as we continue through the program. But I say modestly and materially, still well within the range of our normal color that we normally expect R&D to flow in. Your question around the launch assistance payments, they'll continue to flow. I don't have the exact schedule of that, but it will cause that [indiscernible] to be a lumpy as it's always been and we'll report that to you when it gets sort of at a line. But expect net-net sort of a modest immaterial growth in R&D next year and then again, the following year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just totally changing gears to the balance sheet. As you well know, right, the balance sheet is extraordinarily strong. Do you have any thoughts on maybe levering up a little bit? Or what you think about that? Or what do you think the proper capital struc
componenttext: Just totally changing gears to the balance sheet. As you well know, right, the balance sheet is extraordinarily strong. Do you have any thoughts on maybe levering up a little bit? Or what you think about that? Or what do you think the proper capital structure is for general dynamics?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think consistent with the position we held in the past is levering up really is not something we're interested in, particularly as it relates to our current capital deployment approach of share repurchase and dividends. Conferring debt for the proper
componenttext: So I think consistent with the position we held in the past is levering up really is not something we're interested in, particularly as it relates to our current capital deployment approach of share repurchase and dividends. Conferring debt for the proper long-term strategic opportunity is certainly out there, but that's something that we'll continue to hold as dry powder until the right opportunity shows up.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So fed IT, I think what you're saying is what we anticipated seeing the same players just with new T-shirts, new brands. And the pipeline is it is what it has been. And I think to Jason's point it has always been our view that if we found something attrac
componenttext: So fed IT, I think what you're saying is what we anticipated seeing the same players just with new T-shirts, new brands. And the pipeline is it is what it has been. And I think to Jason's point it has always been our view that if we found something attractive and very accretive, we would lever up for it. But we haven't been there, and we don't see that as we stay in the moment. I don't think anything has fundamentally changed in the broader portfolio of defense and aerospace portfolio. So that's a little bit, but that's -- I gave you my view of that.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Corporation Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Abigail, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to
componenttext:
Thank you, Abigail, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.40 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7 -- $7.81 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $764 million. Incidentally, we
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin, and good morning all. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.40 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7 -- $7.81 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $764 million. Incidentally, we beat analyst consensus by $0.02, which is hard to do this late in the year.
Revenue and operating earnings were down against the year-ago quarter by 6.6% and 2.9%, respectively. Earnings from continuing operations, however, were up $27 million on the strength of a 50 basis point improvement in operating margin and a lower tax rate.
Similarly, earnings per diluted share from continuing operations were up $0.21, almost 10%. By the way, in connection with the comparisons to the year-ago quarter, let's remember that the fourth quarter 2014 was, and remains, the strongest revenue performance of any quarter in the last 4 years and by no small measure. So it is a very difficult comparison, and that will be true in the business segments as well.
Sequentially, the quarters were very similar. Revenue was down $185 million or 2.3%, but operating earnings were up $2 million on a 40 basis point improvement in margin rate. So all in all, a solid quarter with particularly good performance in the Aerospace group, which I'll speak about in a little bit more detail.
So for the year, where does that leave us? We had fully diluted earnings per share of $9.08 on revenue of $31.47 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $2.97 billion. Return on sales was 9.4%. Revenue for the year was up $617 million or 2%. Operating earnings were up $289 million or 7.4% on a 70 basis point improvement in operating margin.
Earnings from continuing operations were up $292 million or 10.9%, helped by a 200 basis point improvement in the effective tax rate. This, together with share repurchases activity, led quite naturally to a 16% improvement in earnings per share. So all in all, 2015 was a great year, improving significantly over a very good 2014. It was a year of further progress from an operating perspective and revenue growth consistent with our guidance to you at this time last year.
Turning to cash. Free cash flow from operations was $120 million in the quarter. For the year, we had free cash flow from operations of $1.93 billion, which is 65% of earnings from continuing operations. As we advised you at the beginning of the year, free cash flow from operations was not going to reach 100% of net earnings for 3 reasons. First, we are working off a very large advance payment received in 2014 on a major Combat Systems program. Second, we have an increase in operating working capital at Gulfstream, consistent with building numerous aircraft for test and preproduction parts in connection with the G500 and G600 programs. And third, we are also working off large advance payments received in 2014 at NASSCO for commercial shipbuilding programs. All of this will normalize and unwind quite positively, but not until 2017. In 2016, we will continue to have less than our usual robust free cash flow.
Let me give you some color on the quarter and the year in each of the business groups. First, Aerospace. Revenue was down modestly over the year-ago quarter. Sales were down $98 million, but earnings were down just $2 million as a result of a 70 basis point improvement in margin, very nice operating performance.
For the year, revenue was $8.85 billion, and operating earnings were $1.71 billion with an operating margin of 19.3%. This is a year-over-year improvement of 2.3% on sale, 5.9% on earnings and 70 basis points on operating margin. All in all, a very good year at Aerospace, with strong operating leverage and good order intake.
During the quarter, we took down the production rate of the G550 to what would be the sustaining rate through 2016. The G450 will come down modestly in the first quarter of 2016. By the same token, the production rate of the G650 and G650ER were taken up during the second half of 2014 and will be taken up again in 2016 to reflect current demand and our sizable backlog. The production rate on the G650 and G650ER is clearly sustainable for this year and next.
So contrary to what many investors seem to have anticipated, order activity in the quarter was quite good. The book-to-bill at Gulfstream was at least 1:1, both dollar based, 1:1; and in units of green delivery, 1.1:1, with particularly strong demand for the G650 and G650ER. By the way, an interesting data point is that there were more orders for in-production aircraft in 2015 than 2014. All in all, the order activity going into the first quarter of this year is quite good.
Let me say a few words about the large-cabin business jet market in general. We find demand to be reasonable. We see no evidence at Gulfstream of a cyclical decline. The order activity is good but not frenetic, and North America is particularly good. More than 50% of our orders for the year were from North America. I shall also point out that despite the handling by some, our orders from Asia Pacific improved by more than 60% over 2014. In short, this market is not a bull yet, but it is steady from our perspective. We also seem to be picking up some share from other OEMs.
Combat Systems. At Combat, revenue was down $90 million or 5.6%, and earnings were down $37 million or 13.7% on a 140 basis point reduction in operating margin over the year-ago quarter. Nevertheless, a 15.4% operating margin was more than respectable and consistent with our expectations for the group.
Sequentially, the story begins to foretell the future. Sales were up $179 million and earnings were up $16 million. That is 13.3% and 7.3%, respectively. For the full year, sales were down $92 million or 1.6%, and earnings were up $20 million or 2.3% on a 60 basis point improvement in operating margin. This margin expansion is the result of restructuring at both our European and Ordnance and Tactical Systems businesses. By the way, this performance is reasonably consistent with the guidance we provided at this time last year. You may recall that we had guided to flat revenue and earnings. Overall, Combat Systems was a story of revenue reasonably consistent with expectations, an outstanding cost and margin performance.
By the way, in just a moment, Jason's going to give you a little bit more color on this group's revenue performance.
This is a business poised for modest growth in 2016 and quite significant growth in the 2017 through '19 time frame, as we begin delivering on our $19 billion backlog.
Now Marine Systems. The group's revenue of $1.98 billion in the quarter was down $58 million or 2.8% compared to the year-ago quarter and down $105 million or 5%, sequentially. Revenue for the year, however, was up $701 million, a rather extraordinary 9.6%. And recall that this increase in annual revenue follows the $600 million increase in 2014.
Operating earnings were down $21 million or 10.9% against the year-ago quarter and down $9 million or 5% sequentially. For the full year, earnings were up $25 million or 3.6%, in spite of 50 basis point decline in operating margin.
In the Marine group, we guided you at this time last year to revenue growth of 2% to 2.5%, which we exceeded by a fair measure. We forecast margins at 9.5% and wound up at 9.1%. So the story here was better-than-anticipated revenue but not as good as expected operating margin, which left us relatively consistent with our guidance for operating earnings.
The growth in revenue in the year was driven by Electric Boat on 2 Virginia-class construction -- 2 Virginia-class submarine construction and increased engineering work for the Ohio replacement program. This group's margins are the result of a mix shift. Higher engineering work, transitioning to Block IV from Block III, and increased work on commercial Jones Act ships at NASSCO.
IS&T is a business group where, once again, we saw less-than-expected revenue decline, coupled with improved operating performance. Several of our major ground and maritime programs were all funded beyond our plan, improving our sales performance. Margin improvement was a result of greater efficiencies than planned and business unit consolidation, and continuing operating performance across all the portfolio.
Revenue in the quarter was $2.16 billion, down $307 million or 12.4% against the year-ago quarter, a very difficult comparator, as I have mentioned previously. On the other hand, operating earnings of $230 million in the quarter were 8.5% better than the fourth quarter a year ago. On a sequential basis, operating earnings were up $11 million or 5% on the strength of 10.6% margin, 70 basis points better than last quarter.
For the year, revenue was down $194 million or only 2.1%. Remember, this is dramatically less than the 5.5% revenue decline we forecasted in our guidance to you at this time last year. For the year, earnings were up $118 million or 15%, very good operating performance in the face of a 2% revenue decline.
On this call a year ago, I gave you guidance with respect to operating margins in this -- in the 9% range, which we beat by 110 basis points. All in all, we beat forecasted revenue and operating margins. When that happens, the result is significant upside to the forecast.
On this call a year ago, on a company-wide basis, our guidance for 2015 was to expect revenue of $31.3 billion to $31.5 billion, an operating margin rate of 12.8%, a tax rate of 30.5% and a return on sales of 8.7%. We wound up the year with revenue at $31.47 billion, an operating margin rate of 13.3%, an effective tax rate of 27.7% and a return on sales of 9.4%.
Last year at this time, we provided EPS guidance of $8.05 to $8.10. We wound up at $9.08. About 46% of the improvement came from better-than-planned operating performance, $0.05 from the gain on the sale of a small business, $0.30 from a lower-than-planned tax rate and the balance from a lower share count as a result of share repurchases. Certainly, a great year by any measure.
So let me provide some thoughts about 2016, initially by group and then on a company-wide roll-up. In Aerospace, we expect revenue to be approximately $8.9 billion, up very modestly; margin rate should be down 10 to 20 basis points; and operating earnings flat to last year. 2017 should look a lot like 2016, with upside in revenue and earnings if we can deliver G500 in the fourth quarter. Revenue and earnings growth will resume with full-scale production and delivery of the G500 and 2018 and the G600 the following year. In Combat, we expect revenue to be up $160 million and the margin rates similar to 2015, with more vigorous growth of both revenue and earnings in 2017, 2018 and '19. The Marine group is expected to have revenues similar to 2015, but improved operating earnings as a result of operating margins in the mid-9% range.
Revenue in 2017 and 2018 will have growth of a couple of hundred million a year, an additional $0.5 billion in 2019 growth. 
Finally, in IS&T, we expect a modest improvement in revenue and a 20 to 30 basis point decline in operating margin. Let me remind you again that a gain on the sale of a business was included in 2015's operating earnings and margin rate. This will result in essentially flat operating earnings year-over-year. Once again, we should see more solid revenue growth in 2017 and '18.
All of this rolls up to $31.6 billion to $31.8 billion of revenue; operating margin around 13.3%; and return on sales of roughly 9.1%.
Let me emphasize that this plan is purely from operations. It assumes a 29.5% tax rate, assumes -- and assumes we buy only enough shares to hold the share count steady with year-end figures so as to avoid dilution from option exercises. This rolls up to an EPS guidance of around $9.20 per fully diluted share. This compares with last year's guidance of $8.05 to $8.10 at the same time, on the same basis.
Let me also reconcile this forecast of $9.20 to our 2015 year-end result of $9.08. In 2016, we will not have the operating gain from the sale of a business. That gain was $0.05 of EPS. In 2016, we will have higher interest expense with a $0.02 negative impact to 2016 EPS. We will also have a higher effective tax rate in 2016 that will cost us $0.23 per share.
Foreign exchange headwinds at current FX rates will cost another $0.04 of EPS compared to 2015. On a pro forma basis, this adjusts 2015 to $8.74, and gives us a 5% adjusted growth in forecasted 2016 EPS before deployment of capital.
With respect to the quarterly progression for EPS, it looks like most years. So divide our guidance by 4 and take $0.20 off of Q1, $0.10 off Q2, leave Q3 even and about 40 -- $0.30 up in Q4. So much like last year, beating our guidance must come from outperforming the operating plan and the effect of capital deployment.
With respect to the deployment of capital, we anticipate using all of our free cash flow in 2016 for dividends and share repurchase. While we don't anticipate a robust year from a free cash flow perspective for the reasons I have previously described, we will use balance sheet cash to some degree to supplement our free cash flow for share repurchase activity. I'll have more to say on this subject at the end of the first quarter, as our planning becomes more refined and is approved by our board.
I'd now like to turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. As we discussed previously, we felt more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility in 2015 than we have in the past. In particular, this issue has had a negative impact on our growth ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. As we discussed previously, we felt more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility in 2015 than we have in the past. In particular, this issue has had a negative impact on our growth experience in our Combat Systems group, given their increasing international activity.
As Phebe pointed out, the group's full year revenue was down 1.6% compared to 2014. But as foreign exchange rates, particularly the U.S. dollar to the euro and to the Canadian dollar, held constant from 2014 to this year, the group's sales would have actually increased by 6.4% in 2015.
For the company as a whole, this would have taken our 2% top line growth over 2014 to almost 4%. As a reminder, this had nothing to do with any economic exposure or losses. This is merely the translation of our various international indigenous businesses into U.S. dollars for consolidated reporting purposes and the negative effect on that translation that comes with a strengthening dollar.
Given where we see the mix of Combat Systems programs in the years ahead, we expect foreign currency fluctuations to be an ongoing part of the group's story.
Net interest expense in the quarter was $19 million, consistent with the fourth quarter of 2014. For the year, interest expense was $83 million, $3 million less than the year before due to the repayment of $500 million of fixed rate notes that occurred in 2015. For 2016, we expect net interest expense of around $95 million, and the increase is due primarily to less interest income as we've deployed cash off the balance sheet.
As we deployed that cash over the year, we've moved from a net cash position of cash in excess of debt of $1 billion at the end of 2014 to a net debt position of $614 million. And I'll walk through those capital deployment activities in just a minute.
Our effective tax rate was 27.7% for the year, right in the ballpark and slightly lower than the 28% we forecasted at the end of the third quarter. The lower outcome is attributable to favorable contract closeouts with the IRS and Congress's enactment of tax extenders in late December, in particular, the research and experimentation credit. For the year, the research tax credit extension benefited our rate by about 50 basis points, but was offset by some onetime unfavorable effects of other provisions in the extenders law. The combined effect was a 20 basis point reduction in the 2015 effective rate or about $0.02 per share.
You may recall at this time last year that given our increasing international presence, we considered the new normal for our effective tax rate to be in the 30% to 30.5% range.
For 2016, with the research tax credit now permanent, we expect an effective tax rate in the mid-29% range.
Moving on to our pension plans. We contributed about $185 million to our pension plans in 2015, as forecast. And for 2016, we expect that amount to be approximately $200 million, to be contributed mostly during the third quarter.
And finally, on the capital deployment front. To summarize our activities for the year, we spent approximately $3.2 billion on share repurchases. And when you combine those share repurchases with our dividend payments, we used $4.1 billion in shareholder-friendly actions in 2015 or 2.1x our free cash flow from operations for the year.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Peter Arment with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Peter Arment with Sterne Agee.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe this is a good opportunity just because we haven't spoke since the budget deal. And maybe you could just give us kind of your overview, how you see that impacting domestically. And also related to that, are you seeing any changes on the inter
componenttext: Phebe, maybe this is a good opportunity just because we haven't spoke since the budget deal. And maybe you could just give us kind of your overview, how you see that impacting domestically. And also related to that, are you seeing any changes on the international order front, just given what has happened with the oil prices with any of your customers?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the budget deal provided us funding in line with -- exactly in line with what we anticipated. So no surprises there, and some upside, frankly, in a couple of areas. But that stability is critical and I think very helpful as we think through the defense
componenttext: So the budget deal provided us funding in line with -- exactly in line with what we anticipated. So no surprises there, and some upside, frankly, in a couple of areas. But that stability is critical and I think very helpful as we think through the defense portfolio for the next year or 2. So that was, I think, very helpful. But as I said, it was consistent with what we had anticipated. With respect to international orders, we have continued to increase, and particularly on the Combat Systems side, increased our order activity internationally. And so far, we have yet to see any impact from oil prices in the Mid East. As we talked a lot in the past, from my perspective, defense spending is completely determined by the threat. And the threat environment in that world has gotten nothing but worst. So we're very sensitive to our customers' needs and requirements and we work carefully with them to ensure that we can provide them what they need when they want it, in terms that are favorable to us and which they can accommodate. I would also remind you, by the way, that most of our orders in that part of the world are government-to-government, which provides some stability. So that is a benefit to us as well, as we look forward.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You had talked a little bit about free cash flow not being that robust this year and you had talked about last -- I guess, in 2015, because of the Aerospace investments. Can you just walk through what kind of expectations and then what changes as you go i
componenttext: You had talked a little bit about free cash flow not being that robust this year and you had talked about last -- I guess, in 2015, because of the Aerospace investments. Can you just walk through what kind of expectations and then what changes as you go into 2017 that makes it start to see us return to 100% conversion?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's all 3 of -- it's a reversal, an unwinding of all 3 of the factors that we've talked about impacting 2015 and '16, but let's take Gulfstream. We're continuing to build demonstration and test aircraft -- test aircraft for both the G500 and G600.
componenttext: Well, it's all 3 of -- it's a reversal, an unwinding of all 3 of the factors that we've talked about impacting 2015 and '16, but let's take Gulfstream. We're continuing to build demonstration and test aircraft -- test aircraft for both the G500 and G600. Our capital deployment -- or our CapEx is largely done at Gulfstream, but that buildup in inventory will continue until we begin to take or deliver the G500 and G600. So that will help unwind that buildup of working capital at Gulfstream. NASSCO will have completed its Jones Act ships in '17, and we anticipate a number of orders coming into the Marine group that, of course, carry cash. And in Combat Systems, we will begin to get additional cash as we ramp up to a full-rate production on a number of our international quarters. So 2015, '16, lighter than we're normal -- than we're used to. But 2017 will be above -- every expectation we have is that it will be above 100% of net income.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any way to quantify what percentage of net income you're expecting this year?
componenttext: Any way to quantify what percentage of net income you're expecting this year?
