headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, VP for
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, VP for Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to s
componenttext:
Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We've reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than th
componenttext:
Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We've reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than the year-ago quarter. We were also $0.13 a share better than consensus. 
With respect to consensus, it would appear that the sell side anticipated about $200 million more revenue, lower margin and a somewhat higher tax rate. Compared to consensus, we had about $30 million more in operating earnings on higher-margin, $10 million less in taxes resulting in about $40 million more in net earnings. The big driver in the quarter was the operational performance. Compared to the year-ago quarter, revenue of $7.67 billion was $217 million lower. However, earnings of $758 million were up $6 million on a 30-basis-point improvement in operating margin and 140-basis-point lower effective tax rate. 
I should note that our earnings in the year-ago quarter included a gain on the sale of our commercial cyber business, excluding that gain, there is a 60-basis-point improvement in operating legend. Sequentially, revenue was down $59 million or less than 1% and earnings from continuing operations were up $28 million on a 40-basis-point improvement in operating margin and a lower effective tax rate. 
Let me turn briefly to the first half of 2016 as compared to the first half of '15. Revenue was down 1.8% against the first half of 2015. On the other hand, operating earnings were up $15 million. Operating margins were 30 basis points better. Earnings from continuing operations were up $20 million, EPS was $0.36 better. 
In short, we're off to a good start ahead of both our internal plan and external expectations. That leads quite naturally to the guidance increase reflected in the press release. I'll provide additional color on that guidance shortly. But first let me give you some perspective on the segment reporting for the quarter and for the half. I'll then conclude with some comments on the outlook for each segment for the remainder of the year and wrap that into our EPS guidance. 
First, Aerospace. Aerospace had a very good quarter. Revenue of $2.13 billion was $124 million lower than the year-ago quarter. Operating earnings of $434 million or only $5 million less on a 90-basis-point improvement in operating margin. Importantly, on a sequential basis, revenue was up $147 million or 7.4% and operating earnings were up $23 million or 5.6%. For the first half, revenue at $4.12 billion is off $245 million against last year, reflecting planned production cuts to the $450 million and the $550 million, offset in part by increased delivery of the $650 million. However, earnings at $845 million are only $25 million -- or off only $25 million on a 60-basis-point improvement in margin. In short, at $845 million in operating earnings to the first half of the year, we are well positioned to achieve or exceed our earning goals for the year. 
By the way, recall that last year, we told you that we had in Q1 a positive supply of settlement. After that contribution, earnings actually would have been up this year. So let me give you some commentary about the order activity in the quarter and then some observations about the current state of the market. First, on a numerical unit basis, we had 50% more orders than we did in the first quarter. However, the mix was not as advantageous. In other words, think about it this way, we sold more mid-cabin in the quarter than in the first quarter. So the dollar-based book to bill was not much better, about 1/3 of our orders in the quarter were mid-cabin. Activity in interest level were good throughout the quarter, but at the end of the quarter, when many transactions typically closed, activity almost seized as a result of the events associated with the Brexit vote. However, those customers did not go away and are continuing to pursue transactions with us this quarter. 
We are quite optimistic regarding third quarter sales activity. Active prospects are very good, better than at any time in the year. The U.S. jobs report earlier this month slightly improved economic stories in the U.S. and, to a lesser extent, Europe, coupled with the quick market recovery from the initial Brexit vote reaction seem to have accelerated the activity level on our prospects. We fully expect a good third quarter and second half from an order perspective. 
You may recall that in the G500 made its flight in the second quarter last year. This month, it made its international debut at the Airshow. T4, that's the fourth test article, made the flight from Savannah to Farnborough in 6 hours and 55 minutes, traveling at a steady 0.9 Mack. Flight test is going very well and we are on or somewhat ahead of schedule. We look forward to the first flight of the G600 late this year. 
Let's take a look at Combat. They had a very solid quarter. Revenue was $1.32 billion, $93 million less than the second quarter last year. However, 60-basis-point improvement in operating margins resulted in a modest $7 million increase in operating earnings over the year-ago quarter. All in all, very good operating leverage and an outstanding 16.7%. 
On a sequential basis, revenue was up $42 million or 3.3% and operating earnings were up $2 million, about 1%. For the first half, revenue was down $183 million or 6.6% against the first half of 2015. Operating earnings, on the other hand, were up $6 million on a 130-basis-point margin expansion. Pretty impressive operating performance. 
Work is progressing quite well in our international orders, with prototypes in production for both our Program and our Canadian Mideast contract. We were also awarded a contract to begin fast yielding of the Gun Stryker. 
With respect to the Marine group, revenue of $1.99 billion was $14 million lower than Q2 a year ago. Operating earnings were off $6 million against the year-ago quarter and operating margins were off 20 basis points. On a sequential basis, revenue was down $144 million due to timing on summary material purchases. Operating earnings were down $11 million, resulting in a modest 10-basis-point improvement in operating margin. 
For the first half, revenue of $4.1 billion was up $174 million or 4.4% against the first half of '15. Operating earnings were essentially the same on somewhat lower margins. Marine Systems has been a compelling growth story for us and will continue to be so. We have some work to do on margins in the second half. 
Turning to IS&T, that group continues to do well. Revenue of $2.2 billion and operating earnings of $244 million were up against the year-ago quarter, $14 million and $7 million, respectively. There was a 20 basis point improvement in operating margin, which was particularly impressive when one considers that the sale of the commercial cyber product business contributed 100 basis points of margin in the year-ago quarter. Sequentially, revenue was lower by $104 million, but operating earnings were down only $4 million, or 1.6% on a 30 basis point improvement in margin. This 10.9% margin is a strongest in nearly 5 years. 
The story for the first half as much the same, revenue was down $23 million, 1/2 of a percent, and operating earnings were up $38 million or 8.4% on a 90 basis point improvement of margin. So once again, very strong operating leverage. 
This group also tells a story about building the backlog through the first half. Book to bill at about 1.3, which marks the eighth quarter in the last 10 quarters the group has achieved a book to bill equal to or greater than one-to-one. In short, we believe all this leaves us poised for a good second half. 
So turning to guidance. Let me provide this some guidance for the year for each segment and then compare it to what we told you in January and then wrap it up into our EPS guidance. 
For Aerospace. Our guidance was to expect revenue somewhat lower than 2015 and margins somewhat higher than 2015, leading to flat operating earnings. We now expect to be between $8.5 billion and $8.6 billion of revenue, with margins slightly above 20%. This implies a slight pressure on margins in the second half, particularly in the third quarter. This will result in operating earnings the same as last year, even if slightly better. Despite all the handling by some, these 2 businesses will continue to perform well. 
So for Combat Systems, our previous guidance was to expect revenue of approximately $5.8 billion and margins in the mid-15% area. We now expect revenue of somewhat over $5.7 billion and margins at 16% to 16.1%. Revenue will see strong uplift in the fourth quarter. The difference in revenue guidance is simply from timing. 
For the Marine group, we previously guided to revenue of $8 billion and margins in the mid-9% range. We now expect revenue to be between 8.1% and $8.2 billion and margins around 9.2%. 
For IS&T, we guided to revenue of about $9 billion and margins approaching double digits. It now appears that our revenue guidance was good, with slight upward pressure and that operating margins will be somewhat better than 10.5% for the year. 
So all of this rolls up into revenue for GD of about $31.5 billion. Operating margins of 13.7% to 13.8%, net income somewhat more than the $3 billion and the return on sale of around 9.6%. Compared to our initial guidance, we will have somewhat lower revenue with higher operating income on higher margins, a somewhat lower tax rate and a lower share count, which permits us to increase our EPS guidance to $9.70. To help you further, our original EPS guidance was $9.20 per share. The $0.50 difference is $0.24 from operations, $0.09 from a lower tax rate and $0.17 from share repurchases. If you think about the progression for the remainder of the year, third quarter should be somewhat weaker than the second, but much like the first, followed by a very strong fourth quarter. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Jason Aiken, our CFO.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems group. And when you compare that group's results to the first half of 2016 to the similar period a year ago, our 2016 revenue would have been higher by approximately $75 million at the exchange rate that prevailed in the first half of 2015, remained in effect this year. And for the company as a whole, revenue would have been a little over $100 million higher. 
Moving down the income statement. Our net interest expense in the quarter was $23 million versus $20 million in the second quarter of 2015. That brings the interest expense for the first half of the year to $45 million versus $41 million for the same period in 2015. For 2016, we continue to expect interest expense to be approximately $95 million, up from 2015 due to lower cash balances resulting from our capital deployment activities, which I'll cover it just a minute. 
We continue to expect free cash flow this year to look similar to 2015, but more related to the latter part of the year. At the end of the quarter, our balance sheet reflect the cash balance of $1.9 billion and a net debt position of $1.5 billion, both essentially unchanged from the end of the first quarter. Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we had $500 million of fixed rate notes mature and we're in the process of refinancing that that as we speak. We intend to replace that debt and raise an additional $500 million for general corporate purposes to include share repurchases. 
Our effective tax rate was 27.7% for the quarter. This was lower than our original expectation as we adopted a new accounting standard that altered the accounting for tax benefits associated with our stock option and restricted stock. 
In a nutshell, these tax benefits are now treated as a permanent benefit that impact our effective tax rate. In the second quarter, this change reduced our effective tax rate by approximately 140 basis points. We have a rate at 28.8% year-to-date, and we're now targeting a full year rate right around 29%. 
On the capital deployment front, in the second quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million shares, bringing us to just under 9 million shares in the first half of 2016 for almost $1.2 billion. In total, when combined with the dividend we paid to the first 6 months of the year, we spent $1.6 billion in shareholder friendly capital deployment, more than 2x our free cash flow for the first half. 
Erin, that concludes was my remarks, and I'll turn it back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the call on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with a used inventory
componenttext: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the call on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with a used inventory that's out there and the 650? And then what you saw regionally. Did North America hold in there pretty well?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used planes
componenttext: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used planes in the market. We simply don't not see that. If I count serial numbers, we have 14 on the market right now with 1 pending transaction. We have 186 in service, so that equates to 7.5 of the fleet. That is well below the 10% used to in-service ratio. So that's rather typical. And by the way, we have long anticipated the emergence of a 650 used market. So in my mind, that should be no surprise. I would also note that we have seen minimal impact with a few customers choosing the near term availability rather than wait. So from my perspective, based on the facts and the data, we're quite comfortable that, that used market is appropriate and acting in a rational and typical sort of way. So 650, so if you talk about by model, the 650 demand remains quite active. In our submarkets, subsections of the market, the 450 and 550 are, as we anticipated, during this period of transition to the 500 and 600, complicated the touch by competitor's over production. By the way, I might tell you that the 500 and 600 positions are sold to the lot -- a lot of those positions are sold in '16 and '17. So we like how all of that is shaping up. And with respect to the geographic distribution, about 50% of the orders were North America and I think the rest split between Mid East, Asia-Pacific, Europe and South America, in that order. Okay?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Robert Spingarn of Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Robert Spingarn of Crdit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to switch to Marine for a moment, Phebe. You've got -- you guided for us earlier but you have a lot going on there. You've got the Block IV pricing going up. There's growth in ORP funding. When would we start to see some real improvement in sales
componenttext: I wanted to switch to Marine for a moment, Phebe. You've got -- you guided for us earlier but you have a lot going on there. You've got the Block IV pricing going up. There's growth in ORP funding. When would we start to see some real improvement in sales from all of these positives?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been experiencing that improvement, but when you look at the Navy's plan to continue with the Gulfstream or the Virginia class deliveries as well as our replacement, we see that we get some real nice ignition starting in 19 when we have long t
componenttext: Well, we've been experiencing that improvement, but when you look at the Navy's plan to continue with the Gulfstream or the Virginia class deliveries as well as our replacement, we see that we get some real nice ignition starting in 19 when we have long the delivery and how we're anticipating based on the Navy plan, long delivery in 19. But let's not forget, this has been a very nice steady quarter-over-quarter performance.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: True. How would the TAOX factor in? And does that impact NASSCO's margins later through this year and next year, when there?
componenttext: True. How would the TAOX factor in? And does that impact NASSCO's margins later through this year and next year, when there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the TAOX, let's remember that, that -- our award was for 1 ship and multiple 5 options subject to the request authorization and appropriation, right? So those are right and our wheel house and we ought to be able to perform very nicely on those. And it
componenttext: So the TAOX, let's remember that, that -- our award was for 1 ship and multiple 5 options subject to the request authorization and appropriation, right? So those are right and our wheel house and we ought to be able to perform very nicely on those. And it positions us well for the 17 ships in the Navy contract. It was an unusual award, but there were no surprises and I think from is an unusual contracting process, but from my point of view, there were no surprises because it sort of lined up with who does what well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, you talked a lot about the earnings an d the revenue for the year. In the past, you've talked about free cash flow conversion relative to last year. So now with the higher net income, should we still see a similar conversion and somewhat related, w
componenttext: Phebe, you talked a lot about the earnings an d the revenue for the year. In the past, you've talked about free cash flow conversion relative to last year. So now with the higher net income, should we still see a similar conversion and somewhat related, we knew you're going to be eating into those international combat advances, but really, what should that advances line look like when we get to the end of the year on the balance sheet?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we had
componenttext: Sam, as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we had last year from a timing standpoint. As it relates to the advances, we'll continue to draw down on those. So you'll see that balance -- you've seen it come down throughout the first half of the year and you'll see that continue as we continue to make progress on the production side of those contracts through the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But coming down at the same rate?
componenttext: But coming down at the same rate?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have the exact specifics on that, we can perhaps talk after the call on that, but directionally, yes, we'll see it continue to come down.
componenttext: I don't have the exact specifics on that, we can perhaps talk after the call on that, but directionally, yes, we'll see it continue to come down.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Doug Harned of Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Doug Harned of Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the market situation at Gulfstream. I mean, margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're going
componenttext: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the market situation at Gulfstream. I mean, margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're going through a transition to the new programs, you have lower rate on the 450 and 550. And when you roll that forward, do you expect, if you have to take rate down, perhaps even more on the 450 and 550, can you keep that margin level through the product transition?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out -- they're are driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the
componenttext: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out -- they're are driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the 650's nice contribution. So when I think about that, that and our performance on service has been quite nice through the course of the year. So I have a great deal of confidence that we can continue to maintain our profitability as we go through. We'll have to modify it somewhat, our profitability going through this transition period.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?
componenttext: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we pretty much planned in the rate on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see anymore reduction on the 450. And the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look. Our job is to keep earnings up as high as possible d
componenttext: Well, we pretty much planned in the rate on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see anymore reduction on the 450. And the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look. Our job is to keep earnings up as high as possible during this transition period and manage our margins. We're going to continue to do that. I think we've demonstrated that track record in the last 6 quarters and we're going to continue going forward.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Howard Rubel of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Howard Rubel of Jefferies.

componenttext: First, Phebe, I have a clarification. I think you said 500, 600 sold in '16 and '17. Did you mean that you're largely sold out in '17 and '18?

componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm sorry if I wasn't clear on that. The 650 is sold out in its entirety through the first quarter -- or through 2016 and also in its entirety in 2017. So when we look at the order activity on the 500 and 600, what I'm saying is that our expectations
componenttext: Yes. I'm sorry if I wasn't clear on that. The 650 is sold out in its entirety through the first quarter -- or through 2016 and also in its entirety in 2017. So when we look at the order activity on the 500 and 600, what I'm saying is that our expectations for our entering into service will remain the same. We have, in that projection, we have sold an awful lot of our both of those 500 and 600s. So that positions us very well, I think.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm sorry. Again, so '17 and '18 for the 500 and 600 are largely sold, is that how I'm hearing this?
componenttext: So I'm sorry. Again, so '17 and '18 for the 500 and 600 are largely sold, is that how I'm hearing this?

componenttext: Yes. It's on a lot of sales.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow this. It sounds like though there were some adjustments to the large cabin delivery schedule. Could you articulate where you are for this year? And I guess you probably won't -- and then maybe if can address some elements of how yo
componenttext: And then just to follow this. It sounds like though there were some adjustments to the large cabin delivery schedule. Could you articulate where you are for this year? And I guess you probably won't -- and then maybe if can address some elements of how you're thinking about '17?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't wanted to get into '17 at the moment. Because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year
componenttext: So I don't wanted to get into '17 at the moment. Because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year have not changed. So we've kept them the same as when we start this plan. Revenue is impacted in '16 by a couple of factors. 1, we have 1 less green airplane, I think it's the 280, and 6 fewer completions. We're moving these completions from this year in the next, largely because of customer preferences on when they want to take the plane. And then we got a mix of other smaller puts and takes.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Gursky of Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the 500 and 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event of years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of you take some of the beginning, you have a low until you got
componenttext: Just to follow up on the 500 and 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event of years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of you take some of the beginning, you have a low until you got closer to the entry into service of the aircraft. Wondering if that's still the way that you're thinking about that and at what point, historically, do you see the second end of that barbell begin to pick up? Meaning, when may we see some more orders for the 500 and 600 begin to come in relative to the entry into service? How much before entry into service we may see that to pick back up?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't have perfect clarity about the -- timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectations, building on the good sales we've had here before, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.
componenttext: So I don't have perfect clarity about the -- timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectations, building on the good sales we've had here before, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.

componenttext: Phebe, can you comment on the capital deployment strategy and where your head is currently in terms of M&A? The markets gotten richer or cheaper and property availability has gotten better or worse. And also the repurchase slowdown, is there anything to read there?

componenttext: Yes. So M&A, I don't really have any update for you, but if and when we do something, we'll let you know. [indiscernible] Jason, do you want to talk through the share repurchases?

componenttextpreview: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives, our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second quar
componenttext: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives, our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second quarter and feel like by the balance of the first half of the year, we're right on track and doing exactly what we help hope to do. We deployed, as I said, 2x our free cash flow on share repurchase and dividends. So I don't think you should see those as a signal of any directional shift for us at any time.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclay's.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclay's.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not you're cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reductions actions and furloughs, I didn't kno
componenttext: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not you're cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reductions actions and furloughs, I didn't know if any of that changed from what you initially planned on. And then 1 for Jason. Just on the FX front, I mean, you've called out the U.K. impact. I think you've got a little bit of Swiss impact as well. Should we be -- what should be thinking of in terms of forward impacts if currencies stay where they are? Are there any transactional FX exposures that we should be aware of going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look. As I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really cost management, cost-reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity to estimate the
componenttext: Yes. So look. As I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really cost management, cost-reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity to estimate the goodness that you can achieve until you're really in the moment, right? So we're continuing to manage our cost. I think we've got more way to go and then at the same time, by the way, we've got to continue to improve the 650 and 280 operating margins, which we will do and are doing. And then we've got to ensure that 400 and 500 -- or 450 and 500 maintain their profitability. And so I think that, that will look very nice on track, particularly with regards to the latter.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, if you think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated guid
componenttext: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, if you think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated guidance that Phebe walked you through earlier was actually predicated on the latest rates we have at hand projected to the balance of the year. So that is the latest look at the impact and it's not -- I wouldn't call it material through the balance of the year, but we also don't necessarily take a bet on rates moving further one way or another. So if there is a further movement in the second half, we would obviously tell you about that and it could have an upside or a downside impact to that guidance. Last thing I would say is that there's no, absolutely 0, from our perspective the recessional exposure. This is all strictly, as we discussed before, the translation for U.S. dollar reporting. Everything from a transactional perspective is hedged and has been working effectively up to this point.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ron Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: Phebe and, was wondering if you could just give us a quick update where we stand on the Ohio class program. In terms of what's going on actually, Electric Boat and then what you're looking for over the next coming quarters?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and processed development plan. And think about that as the detailed design
componenttext: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and processed development plan. And think about that as the detailed design and long lead material portion of the procurement process. So the Navy is reviewing that in the moment. I think their plan is to get back to us sometime late summer, early fall. But we are -- that's kind of their call in terms of the cadence of the timing. But that will provide and should provide, depending when we close on that, some upside in this year and then again, as we've talked before, this is a very strong growth engine for us over time.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen & Company.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year and I think at 1 point you said you'd rather takedown production and take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G500?
componenttext: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year and I think at 1 point you said you'd rather takedown production and take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G500?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got
componenttext: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got to bring down the production on the 450, 550, while ramping up the production of the 500 and 600. The ease of this is somewhat benefited or somewhat benefit from the fact that these 2 sets of airplanes are built in completely different facilities. So if you're suggesting that we have a gap, it's not an altogether bad thing, as long as we stay on schedule for our deliveries in the 400 -- or 500 and 600, which I see no reason why we can't at the moment. But we're in a good shape for next year on the 450, 550. We've got a little more ways to go. And then we'll set the production rates for the 500 and 600 as we move forward. So does that get to the essence of your question?

componenttext: I was wondering if you could tell us, maybe Jason, of the shortfall in cash flow, free cash flow, relative to net income this year, maybe in kind of qualitative terms. How much of that is related to the construction of flight test articles for G500 and 600? And do all those play test articles go to customers and so to all of those cost more than the inventory?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually go into long-term product design used for the customers. I would say that the outsize, from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, is reall
componenttext: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually go into long-term product design used for the customers. I would say that the outsize, from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, is really more about the international program advances being drawn down. There's some impact on not so much the flight test aircraft impact at Gulfstream, so much as just inventory build toward production. But that's the minor share. The larger share really is about the international advanced draw down.

componenttext: No. I think it's right, Jason. I just thought that to deliver 4 used planes in subsequent quarters, you're probably not going to that much, maybe you will. So I was kind of figuring the used planes would be less, so you got a little less pressure on the profit and got high revenues.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask you 1 on the Navy program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial recapitalization. And I know you have some potential CapEx, bills t
componenttext: I just want to ask you 1 on the Navy program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial recapitalization. And I know you have some potential CapEx, bills to pay, as you think about what would the rates are going to be. So how we decide to your CapEx profile there at Marine, given kind of them sizable bills and maybe you're going to have to pay if they can pay those bills are not.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, but there's often chatter when from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a nuclear deterrent, it g
componenttext: Well, but there's often chatter when from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a nuclear deterrent, it got to build a summary. So that's #1 in my view. And I think that that's afforded by many people and the government on both the executive and the confessional side. So I wouldn't say that the Democratic subchapter and the system suggest walking away from this requirement. So I think in terms of the navy have budgeted here a revenue flow to us that we can easily accommodate the CapEx and the other improvements that we have going forward in terms of the ability to build these. I might also tell you that we've been spending CapEx over the last few years to position ourselves, particularly at a point on the Ohio replacement. So we work very carefully with our and customer to determine what they need, what we need, the funding allocation, who's responsible for what and we're certainly not going to get caught long.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff VP for Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to s
componenttext:
Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than the y
componenttext:
Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than the year-ago quarter. We were also $0.13 a share better than consensus. 
With respect to consensus, it would appear that the sell side anticipated about $200 million more revenue, lower margin and a somewhat higher tax rate. Compared to consensus, we had about $30 million more in operating earnings on higher margins, $10 million less in taxes resulting in about $40 million more in net earnings. The big driver in the quarter was the operational performance. Compared to the year-ago quarter, revenue of $7.67 billion was $217 million lower. However, earnings of $758 million were up $6 million on a 30 basis point improvement in operating margin and 140 basis point lower effective tax rate. 
I should note that our earnings in the year-ago quarter included a gain on the sale of our commercial cyber business, excluding that gain, there is a 60-basis-point improvement in operating margin. Sequentially, revenue was down $59 million or less than 1% and earnings from continuing operations were up $28 million on a 40 basis point improvement in operating margins and a lower effective tax rate. 
Let me turn briefly to the first half of 2016 in compared to the first half of '15. Revenue was down 1.8% against the first half of 2015. On the other hand, operating earnings were up $15 million. Operating margins were 30 basis points better. Earnings from continuing operations were up $20 million, EPS was $0.36 better. 
In short, we're off to a good start ahead of both our internal plan and external expectations. That leads quite naturally to the guidance increase reflected in the press release. I'll provide additional color on that guidance shortly. But first let me give you some perspective on the segment reporting for the quarter and for the half. I'll then conclude with some comments on the outlook for each segment for the remainder of the year and wrap that into our EPS guidance. 
First, Aerospace. Aerospace had a very good quarter. Revenue of $2.13 billion was $124 million lower than the year-ago quarter. Operating earnings of $434 million or only $5 million less on a 90 basis point improvement in operating margins. Importantly, on a sequential basis, revenue was up $147 million or 7.4% and operating earnings were up $23 million or 5.6%. For the first half, revenue at $4.12 billion is off $245 million against last year, reflecting planned production cuts to the 450  and the 550, offset in part by increased delivery of the 650. However, earnings at $845 million are only $25 million  or off only $25 million on a 60 basis point improvement in margin. In short, at $845 million in operating earnings to the first half of the year, we are well positioned to achieve or exceed our earning goal for the year. 
By the way, recall that last year, we told you that we had in Q1 a positive supply of settlement. After that contribution, earnings would actually have been up this year. So let me give you some commentary about order activity in the quarter and then some observations about the current state of the market. First, on a numerical unit basis, we had 50% more orders than we did in the first quarter. However, the mix was not as advantageous. In other words, think about it this way, we sold more mid-cabin in the quarter than in the first quarter. So the dollar-based book to bill was not much better, about 1/3 of our orders in the quarter were mid-cabin. Activity and interest level were good throughout the quarter, but at the end of the quarter, when many transactions typically closed, activity almost seized as a result of the events associated with the Brexit vote. However, those customers did not go away and are continuing to pursue transactions with us this quarter. 
We are quite optimistic regarding third quarter sales activity. Active prospects are very good, better than at any time in the year. The U.S. jobs report earlier this month slightly improved economic stories in the U.S. and, to a lesser extent, in Europe, coupled with the quick market recovery from the initial Brexit vote reaction seem to have accelerated the activity level on our prospects. We fully expect a good third quarter and second half from an order perspective. 
You may recall that the G500 made its flight in the second quarter last year. This month, it made its international debut at the Farnborough Airshow. T4, that's the fourth test article, made the flight from Savannah to Farnborough in 6 hours and 55 minutes, traveling at a steady 0.9 Mack. Flight test is going very well and we are on or somewhat ahead of schedule. We look forward to the first flight of the G600 late this year. 
Let's take a look at Combat. They had a very solid quarter. Revenue was $1.32 billion, $93 million less than the second quarter last year. However, 60 basis point improvement in operating margins resulted in a modest $7 million increase in operating earnings over the year-ago quarter. All in all, very good operating leverage and an outstanding 16.7%. 
On a sequential basis, revenue was up $42 million or 3.3% and operating earnings were up $2 million, about 1%. For the first half, revenue was down $183 million or 6.6% against the first half of 2015. Operating earnings, on the other hand, were up $6 million on a 130 basis point margin expansion, pretty impressive operating performance. 
Work is progressing quite well on our international orders, with prototypes in production for both our AJAX Program and our Canadian Mideast contract. We were also awarded a contract to begin fast yielding of the Upgun Stryker. 
With respect to the Marine group, revenue of $1.99 billion was $14 million lower than Q2 a year ago. Operating earnings were off $6 million against the year-ago quarter and operating margins were off 20 basis points. On a sequential basis, revenue was down $144 million due to timing on summary material purchases. Operating earnings were down $11 million, resulting in a modest 10 basis point improvement in operating margin. 
For the first half, revenue of $4.1 billion was up $174 million or 4.4% against the first half of '15. Operating earnings were essentially the same on somewhat lower margins. Marine Systems has been a compelling growth story for us and will continue to be so. We have some work to do on margins in the second half. 
Turning to IS&T, that group continues to do well. Revenue of $2.2 billion and operating earnings of $244 million were up against the year-ago quarter, $14 million and $7 million, respectively. There was a 20 basis point improvement in operating margin, which was particularly impressive when one considers that the sale of the commercial cyber product business contributed 100 basis points of margin in the year-ago quarter. Sequentially, revenue was lower by $104 million, but operating earnings were down only $4 million, or 1.6% on a 30 basis point improvement in margin. This 10.9% margin is the strongest in nearly 5 years. 
The story for the first half is much the same, revenue was down $23 million, 0.5%, and operating earnings were up $38 million or 8.4% on a 90 basis point improvement of margin. So once again, very strong operating leverage. 
This group also tells a story about building the backlog through the first half. Book-to-bill at about 1.3, which marks the eighth quarter in the last 10 quarters the group has achieved a book-to-bill equal to or greater than 1 to 1. In short, we believe all this leaves us poised for a good second half. 
So turning to guidance. Let me provide just some guidance for the year for each segment and then compare it to what we told you in January and then wrap it up into our EPS guidance. 
For Aerospace. Our guidance was to expect revenue somewhat lower than 2015 and margins somewhat higher than 2015, leading to flat operating earnings. We now expect to be between $8.5 billion and $8.6 billion of revenue, with margins slightly above 20%. This implies a slight pressure on margins in the second half, particularly in the third quarter. This will result in operating earnings the same as last year, even slightly better. Despite all the [ph] hammering by some, these 2 businesses will continue to perform well. 
So for Combat Systems, our previous guidance was to expect revenue of approximately $5.8 billion and margins in the mid-15% area. We now expect revenue of somewhat over $5.7 billion and margins at 16% to 16.1%. Revenue will see strong uplift in the fourth quarter. The difference in revenue guidance is simply from timing. 
For the Marine group, we previously guided to revenue of $8 billion and margins in the mid-9% range. We now expect revenue to be between $8.1 billion and $8.2 billion and margins around 9.2%. 
For IS&T, we guided to revenue of about $9 billion and margins approaching double digits. It now appears that our revenue guidance was good, with slight upward pressure and that operating margins will be somewhat better than 10.5% for the year. 
So all of this rolls up into revenue for GD of about $31.5 billion, operating margins of 13.7% to 13.8%, net income somewhat more than the $3 billion and the return on sales of around 9.6%. Compared to our initial guidance, we will have somewhat lower revenue with higher operating income on higher margins, a somewhat lower tax rate and a lower share count, which permits us to increase our EPS guidance to $9.70. To help you further, our original EPS guidance was $9.20 per share. The $0.50 difference is $0.24 from operations, $0.09 from a lower tax rate and $0.17 from share repurchases. If you think about the progression for the remainder of the year, third quarter should be somewhat weaker than the second, but much like the first, followed by a very strong fourth quarter. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Jason Aiken, our CFO.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems group. And when you compare that group's results to the first half of 2016 to the similar period a year ago, our 2016 revenue would have been higher by approximately $75 million at the exchange rates that prevailed in the first half of 2015, remained in effect this year. And for the company as a whole, revenue would have been a little over $100 million higher. 
Moving down the income statement. Our net interest expense in the quarter was $23 million versus $20 million in the second quarter of 2015. That brings the interest expense for the first half of the year to $45 million versus $41 million for the same period in 2015. For 2016, we continue to expect interest expense to be approximately $95 million, up from 2015 due to lower cash balances resulting from our capital deployment activities, which I'll cover in just a minute. 
We continue to expect free cash flow this year to look similar to 2015, but more weighted to the latter part of the year. At the end of the quarter, our balance sheet reflects the cash balance of $1.9 billion and a net debt position of $1.5 billion, both essentially unchanged from the end of the first quarter. Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we had $500 million of fixed rate notes mature and we're in the process of refinancing that debt as we speak. We intend to replace that debt and raise an additional $500 million for general corporate purposes to include share repurchases. 
Our effective tax rate was 27.7% for the quarter. This was lower than our original expectation as we adopted a new accounting standard that altered the accounting for tax benefits associated with our stock options and restricted stock. 
In a nutshell, these tax benefits are now treated as a permanent benefit that impact our effective tax rate. In the second quarter, this change reduced our effective tax rate by approximately 140 basis points. We're at a rate of 28.8% year-to-date, and we're now targeting a full year rate right around 29%. 
On the capital deployment front, in the second quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million shares, bringing us to just under 9 million shares in the first half of 2016 for almost $1.2 billion. In total, when combined with the dividend we paid to the first 6 months of the year, we spent $1.6 billion in shareholder friendly capital deployment, more than 2x our free cash flow for the first half. 
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn it back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the color on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with the used invento
componenttext: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the color on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with the used inventory that's out there and the 650? And then what you saw regionally. Did North America hold in there pretty well?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used airplan
componenttext: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used airplanes in the market. We simply do not see them. If I count serial numbers, we have 14 on the market right now with 1 pending transaction. We have 186 in service, so that equates to 7.5 of the fleet. That is well below the 10% used to in-service ratio. So that's rather typical. And by the way, we have long anticipated the emergence of a 650 used market. So in my mind, there should be no surprise. I would also note that we have seen minimal impact with a few customers choosing the near term availability rather than wait. So from my perspective, based on the facts and the data, we're quite comfortable that, that used market is appropriate and acting in a rational and typical sort of way. So 650, so if you talk about by model, the 650 demand remains quite active. In our submarkets, subsections of the markets, the 450 and 550 are, as we anticipated, during this period of transition to the 500 and 600, complicated the touch by competitor's over production. By the way, I might tell you that the 500 and 600 positions are sold to a lot of -- a lot of those positions are sold in '16 and '17. So we like how all of that is shaping up. And with respect to the geographic distribution, about 50% of the orders were North America and I think the rest split between Mid East, Asia-Pacific, Europe and South America, in that order. Okay?

componenttext: I wanted to switch to Marine for a moment, Phebe. You've got -- you guided for us earlier, but you have a lot going on there. You've got the Block IV pricing going up. componenttext: Well, we've been experiencing that improvement, but when we look at the Navy's plan to continue with the Gulfstream or the Virginia class deliveries as well as our replacement, we see that we get some real nice ignition starting in '19 when we have long lead delivery how we're anticipating based on the Navy plan, long lead delivery in '19. But let's not forget, this has been a very nice steady quarter-over-quarter performance.

componenttext: So the TAOX, let's remember that, that -- our award was for 1 ship and multiple I think with 5 options subject to the request, authorization and appropriation, right? componenttext: Phebe, you talked a lot about the earnings and the revenue for the year. In the past, you've talked about free cash flow conversion relative to last year. headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, so as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we
componenttext: Sam, so as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we had last year from a timing standpoint. As it relates to the advances, we'll continue to draw down on those. So you'll see that balance -- you've seen it come down throughout the first half of the year and we'll see that continue as we continue to make progress on the production side of those contracts through the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the margin situation of Gulfstream. I mean, the margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're go
componenttext: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the margin situation of Gulfstream. I mean, the margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're going through a transition to the new programs, you have lower rate on the 450 and 550. And when you roll that forward, do you expect -- if you have to take rate down, perhaps even more on the 450 and 550, can you keep that margin level through the product transition?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but the margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out, they're driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the 65
componenttext: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but the margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out, they're driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the 650's nice contribution. So when I think about that, that and our performance on service has been quite nice through the course of the year. So I have a great deal of confidence that we can continue to maintain our profitability as we go through. We'll have to modify it somewhat, but with our profitability going through this transition period.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?
componenttext: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've pretty much planned in the rates on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see anymore reduction on the 450. In the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look, our job is to keep earnings up as high as possibl
componenttext: Well, we've pretty much planned in the rates on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see anymore reduction on the 450. In the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look, our job is to keep earnings up as high as possible during this transition period and manage our margins. We're going to continue to do that. I think we've demonstrated that track record in the last 6 quarters and we're going to continue going forward.

componenttext: And then just to follow this. It sounds like though there were some adjustments to the large cabin delivery schedule. Could you articulate where you are for this year? And I guess you probably won't. And then maybe if can address some elements of how you're thinking about '17?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't want to get into '17 at the moment, because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year ha
componenttext: So I don't want to get into '17 at the moment, because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year have not changed. So we've kept them the same as when we set this plan. Revenue is impacted in '16 by a couple of factors. 1, we have 1 less green airplane, I think it's the 280, and 6 fewer completions. We're moving these completions from this year into next, largely because of customer preferences on when they want to take the plane. And then we got a mix of other smaller puts and takes.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the 500 and the 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event a few years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of barbelled, you take some at the beginning. We'd have
componenttext: Just to follow up on the 500 and the 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event a few years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of barbelled, you take some at the beginning. We'd have a low until you got closer to the entry into service of the aircraft. Wondering if that's still the way that you're thinking about that? And at what point, historically, do you see the second end of that barbell begin to pick up? Meaning, when might we see some more orders for the 500 and 600 begin to come in relative to the entry into service? How much before entry into service we see that to pick back up?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't have perfect clarity about the precise timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectation, building on the good sales we've had here before, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.
componenttext: So I don't have perfect clarity about the precise timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectation, building on the good sales we've had here before, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.

componenttextpreview: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives, our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second quar
componenttext: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives, our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second quarter and feel like by the balance of the first half of the year, we're right on track and doing exactly what we had hoped to do. We deployed, as I said, 2x our free cash flow on share repurchase and dividends. So I don't think you should see those as a signal of any directional shift for us at any time.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclays.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not your cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reduction actions and furloughs, I didn't know i
componenttext: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not your cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reduction actions and furloughs, I didn't know if any of that changed from what you initially planned on. And then 1 for Jason. Just on the FX front, I mean, you've called out the U.K. impact. I think you've got a little bit of Swiss impact as well. Should we be -- what should we be thinking of in terms of forward impacts if currencies stay where they are? Are there any transactional FX exposures that we should be aware of going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, as I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't the same in each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really the cost management, cost reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity
componenttext: Yes. So look, as I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't the same in each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really the cost management, cost reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity to estimate the goodness that you can achieve until you're really in the moment, right? So we're continuing to manage our cost. I think we've got more way to go. And then at the same time, by the way, we've got to continue to improve the 650 and 280 operating margins, which we will do and are doing. And then we've got to ensure that 400 and 500 -- or 450 and 500 maintain their profitability. And so I think that, that will look very nice on track, particularly with respect to the latter.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, you think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated guidanc
componenttext: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, you think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated guidance that Phebe walked you through earlier was actually predicated on the latest rates we have at hand projected to the balance of the year. So that is the latest look at the impact and it's not -- I wouldn't call it material through the balance of the year, but we also don't necessarily take a bet on rates moving further one way or another. So if there is a further movement in the second half, we would obviously tell you about that and it could have an upside or a downside impact to that guidance. The last thing I would say is that there's no, absolutely 0, from our perspective transactional exposure. This is all strictly, as we've discussed before, the translation for U.S. dollar reporting. Everything from a transactional perspective is hedged and has been working effectively up to this point.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I was wondering if you could just give us a quick update where we stand on the Ohio class program. In terms of what's going on actually you had Electric Boat and then what you're looking for over the next coming quarters?
componenttext: Phebe, I was wondering if you could just give us a quick update where we stand on the Ohio class program. In terms of what's going on actually you had Electric Boat and then what you're looking for over the next coming quarters?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and process development plan. And think about that as the detailed design an
componenttext: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and process development plan. And think about that as the detailed design and long lead material portion of the procurement process. So the Navy is reviewing that in the moment. I think their plan is to get back to us sometime late summer or early fall. But we are -- that's kind of their call in terms of the cadence of the timing. But that will provide and should provide, depending when we close on that, some upside in this year. And then again, as we've talked before, this is a very strong growth engine for us over time.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year? And I think at 1 point you said you'd rather takedown production and take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G500?
componenttext: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year? And I think at 1 point you said you'd rather takedown production and take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G500?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got
componenttext: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got to bring down the production on the 450, 550, while ramping up the production of the 500 and 600. The ease of this is somewhat benefited or somewhat benefits from the fact that these 2 sets of airplanes are built in completely different facilities. So if you're suggesting that we have a gap, it's not an altogether bad thing, as long as we stay on schedule for our deliveries in the 400 -- or 500 and 600, which I see no reason why we can't at the moment. But we're in a good shape for next year on the 450, 550. We've got a little ways more to go. And then we'll set the production rates for the 500 and 600 as we move forward. So does that get to the essence of your question?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful.
componenttext: That's helpful.
