headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could tell us, maybe Jason, of the shortfall in cash flow, free cash flow, relative to net income this year, maybe in kind of qualitative terms, how much of that is related to the construction of flight test articles for G500 and 60
componenttext: I was wondering if you could tell us, maybe Jason, of the shortfall in cash flow, free cash flow, relative to net income this year, maybe in kind of qualitative terms, how much of that is related to the construction of flight test articles for G500 and 600? And do all those flight test articles go to customers and so did all of those cost go into inventory?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually they go into long-term product design used for the customers. I would say that the outsize -- from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, i
componenttext: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually they go into long-term product design used for the customers. I would say that the outsize -- from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, is really more about the international program advances being drawn down. There's some impact on not so much the flight test aircraft impact at Gulfstream, so much as just inventory build toward production, but that's the minor share. The larger share really is about the international advanced draw down.

And I would assume that, that would have deflated the margin you reported as high as it was. So when you go to the second half and you have higher revenues, why did this -- the margin be somewhat less than what it was this quarter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, I'll take that. The revenues for the quarter were right around $40 million, I believe, is the number for preowned. And as is typical, it's right around breakeven, maybe $1 million or $2 million loss associated with those, which is pretty typica
componenttext: So George, I'll take that. The revenues for the quarter were right around $40 million, I believe, is the number for preowned. And as is typical, it's right around breakeven, maybe $1 million or $2 million loss associated with those, which is pretty typical. If I understand your question, for the balance of the year, we do have profiled, as we've talked about before, an expectation of additional preowned coming into inventory and being sold, which actually is consistent with the point Phebe made before with a little bit of a downtick in margins, particularly in the third quarter. So I think those are consistent, unless I misunderstood your question about the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: No. I think it's right, Jason. I just thought that to deliver 4 used planes in subsequent quarters, you're probably not going do that much, maybe you will. So I was kind of figuring the used planes would be less, so you got a little less pressure on the profit and you got higher revenues. You've got higher revenue.

componenttext: Yes. So we are in the third and, more importantly, in the fourth quarter beginning to move from our -- as the domestic land forces contract, some of those begin to taper down, we are increasing our international production. So we have -- we've got -- that's really the margin pressure, simply a question of mix. As long as operating performance is good, these guys have done very well, but they've got to come down their learning curves, right?

componenttext: So if I understand your question properly, we had -- our sales on the 280 were a little different or a little better than we had anticipated. componenttext: Yes. I think that that's right. That's always the case, right? We understand our customers needs, but the order in which they want to execute replacement of their fleet will kind of depend on their imminent needs for their -- imminent needs for the mission that a particular airplane serves. So the good news is, they're selling well, the 280s, but it does impact the bill.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I guess, I'll ask you 1 on the Navy service program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial recapitalization. And I know you have some potential
componenttext: Phebe, I guess, I'll ask you 1 on the Navy service program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial recapitalization. And I know you have some potential CapEx, bills to pay, as you think about what would the right rates are going to be. So how you decide on your CapEx profile there at Marine, given kind of the sizable bills that Navy is going to have to pay and if they can pay those bills are not?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, but there's often chatter when we -- and its been true from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a
componenttext: Well, but there's often chatter when we -- and its been true from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a nuclear deterrent, they've got to build this submarine. So that's #1, that's my view. And I think that that's supported by many people and the government on both the executive and the congressional side. So I wouldn't say that, that Democratic some chatter in the system suggest they're walking away from this requirement. So I think in terms of the -- the navy has budgeted here a revenue flow to us that we can easily accommodate the CapEx and the other improvements that we have going forward in terms of the ability to build these. I might also tell you that we've been spending CapEx over the last few years to position ourselves, particularly at the quantum point on the Ohio replacement. So we work very carefully with our navy customer to determine what they need, what we need, the funding allocation, who's responsible for what and we're certainly not going to get caught long.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff VP for Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to s
componenttext:
Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than the y
componenttext:
Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than the year ago quarter. We were also $0.13 a share better than consensus. 
With respect to consensus, it would appear that the sell side anticipated about $200 million more revenue, lower margin and a somewhat higher tax rate. Compared to consensus, we had about $30 million more in operating earnings on higher margins, $10 million less in taxes resulting in about $40 million more in net earnings. The big driver in the quarter was the operational performance. Compared to the year ago quarter, revenue of $7.67 billion was $217 million lower. However, earnings of $758 million were up $6 million on a 30 basis point improvement in operating margin and 140 basis point lower effective tax rate. 
I should note that our earnings in the year ago quarter included a gain on the sale of our commercial cyber business. Excluding that gain, there is a 60-basis-point improvement in operating margins. Sequentially, revenue was down $59 million or less than 1% and earnings from continuing operations were up $28 million on a 40 basis point improvement in operating margins and a lower effective tax rate. 
Let me turn briefly to the first half of 2016 and compare it to the first half of '15. Revenue was down 1.8% against the first half of 2015. On the other hand, operating earnings were up $15 million. Operating margins were 30 basis points better. Earnings from continuing operations were up $20 million, EPS was $0.36 better. 
In short, we're off to a good start ahead of both our internal plan and external expectations. That leads quite naturally to the guidance increase reflected in the press release. I'll provide additional color on that guidance shortly. But first let me give you some perspective on the segment reporting for the quarter and for the half. I'll then conclude with some comments on the outlook for each segment for the remainder of the year and wrap that into our EPS guidance. 
First, Aerospace. Aerospace had a very good quarter. Revenue of $2.13 billion was $124 million lower than the year-ago quarter. Operating earnings of $434 million were only $5 million less on a 90 basis point improvement in operating margins. Importantly, on a sequential basis, revenue was up $147 million or 7.4% and operating earnings were up $23 million or 5.6%. For the first half, revenue at $4.12 billion is off $245 million against last year, reflecting planned production cuts to the 450 and the 550, offset in part by increased delivery of the 650. However, earnings at $845 million are only $25 million or off only $25 million on a 60 basis point improvement in margin. In short, at $845 million in operating earnings for the first half of the year, we are well positioned to achieve or exceed our earning goal for the year. 
By the way, recall that last year, we told you that we had in Q1 a positive supply of settlement. After that contribution, earnings would actually have been up this year. So let me give you some commentary about order activity in the quarter and then some observations about the current state of the market. First, on a numerical unit basis, we had 50% more orders than we did in the first quarter. However, the mix was not as advantageous. In other words, think about it this way, we sold more mid-cabin in the quarter than in the first quarter. So the dollar-based book-to-bill was not much better, about 1/3 of our orders in the quarter were mid-cabin. Activity and interest level were good throughout the quarter, but at the end of the quarter, when many transactions typically close, activity almost ceased as a result of the events associated with the Brexit vote. However, those customers did not go away and are continuing to pursue transactions with us this quarter. 
We are quite optimistic regarding third quarter sales activity. Active prospects are very good, better than at any time in the year. The U.S. jobs report earlier this month, slightly improved economic stories in the U.S. and, to a lesser extent, in Europe, coupled with the quick market recovery from the initial Brexit vote reaction seem to have accelerated the activity level on our prospects. We fully expect a good third quarter and second half from an order perspective. 
You may recall that the G500 made its first flight in the second quarter last year. This month, it made its international debut at the Farnborough Airshow. T4, that's the fourth test article, made the flight from Savannah to Farnborough in 6 hours and 55 minutes, traveling at a steady 0.9 Mach. Flight test is going very well and we are on or somewhat ahead of schedule. We look forward to the first flight of the G600 late this year. 
Let's take a look at Combat. They had a very solid quarter. Revenue was $1.32 billion, $93 million less than the second quarter last year. However, a 60 basis point improvement in operating margins resulted in a modest $7 million increase in operating earnings over the year ago quarter. All in all, very good operating leverage and an outstanding 16.7%. 
On a sequential basis, revenue was up $42 million or 3.3% and operating earnings were up $2 million, about 1%. For the first half, revenue was down $183 million or 6.6% against the first half of 2015. Operating earnings, on the other hand, were up $6 million on a 130 basis point margin expansion, pretty impressive operating performance. 
Work is progressing quite well on our international orders, with prototypes in production for both our AJAX Program and our Canadian Mideast contract. We were also awarded a contract to begin fast yielding[ph] of the Upgun Stryker. 
With respect to the Marine group, revenue of $1.99 billion was $14 million lower than Q2 a year ago. Operating earnings were off $6 million against the year-ago quarter and operating margins were off 20 basis points. On a sequential basis, revenue was down $144 million due to timing on summary material purchases. Operating earnings were down $11 million, resulting in a modest 10 basis point improvement in operating margin. 
For the first half, revenue of $4.1 billion was up $174 million or 4.4% against the first half of '15. Operating earnings were essentially the same on somewhat lower margins. Marine Systems has been a compelling growth story for us and will continue to be so. We have some work to do on margins in the second half. 
Turning to IS&T, that group continues to do well. Revenue of $2.2 billion and operating earnings of $244 million were up against the year ago quarter, $14 million and $7 million, respectively. There was a 20 basis point improvement in operating margin, which was particularly impressive when one considers that the sale of the commercial cyber product business contributed 100 basis points of margin in the year ago quarter. Sequentially, revenue was lower by $104 million, but operating earnings were down only $4 million, or 1.6% on a 30 basis point improvement in margin. This 10.9% margin is the strongest in nearly 5 years. 
The story for the first half is much the same, revenue was down $23 million, 0.5%, and operating earnings were up $38 million or 8.4% on a 90 basis point improvement of margin. So once again, very strong operating leverage. 
This group also tells a story about building the backlog through the first half. Book-to-bill at about 1.3, which marks the eighth quarter in the last 10 quarters the group has achieved a book-to-bill equal to or greater than 1 to 1. In short, we believe all this leaves us poised for a good second half. 
So turning to guidance. Let me provide you some guidance for the year for each segment and then compare it to what we told you in January and then wrap it up into our EPS guidance. 
For Aerospace. Our guidance was to expect revenue somewhat lower than 2015 and margins somewhat higher than 2015, leading to flat operating earnings. We now expect to be between $8.5 billion and $8.6 billion of revenue, with margins slightly above 20%. This implies a slight pressure on margins in the second half, particularly in the third quarter. This will result in operating earnings the same as last year, even slightly better. Despite all the hand wringing by some, these 2 businesses will continue to perform well. 
So for Combat Systems, our previous guidance was to expect revenue of approximately $5.8 billion and margins in the mid-15% area. We now expect revenue of somewhat over $5.7 billion and margins at 16% to 16.1%. Revenue will see strong uplift in the fourth quarter. The difference in revenue guidance is simply from timing. 
For the Marine group, we previously guided to revenue of $8 billion and margins in the mid-9% range. We now expect revenue to be between $8.1 billion and $8.2 billion and margins around 9.2%. 
For IS&T, we guided to revenue of about $9 billion and margins approaching double digits. It now appears that our revenue guidance was good, with slight upward pressure and that operating margins will be somewhat better than 10.5% for the year. 
So all of this rolls up into revenue for GD of about $31.5 billion, operating margins of 13.7% to 13.8%, net income somewhat more than the $3 billion and the return on sales of around 9.6%. Compared to our initial guidance, we will have somewhat lower revenue but higher operating income on higher margins, a somewhat lower tax rate and a lower share count, which permits us to increase our EPS guidance to $9.70. To help you further, our original EPS guidance was $9.20 per share. The $0.50 difference is $0.24 from operations, $0.09 from a lower tax rate and $0.17 from share repurchases. If you think about the progression for the remainder of the year, third quarter should be somewhat weaker than the second, but much like the first, followed by a very strong fourth quarter. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Jason Aiken, our CFO.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems group. And when you compare that group's results to the first half of 2016 to the similar period a year ago, our 2016 revenue would have been higher by approximately $75 million had the exchange rates that prevailed in the first half of 2015, remained in effect this year. And for the company as a whole, revenue would have been a little over $100 million higher. 
Moving down the income statement. Our net interest expense in the quarter was $23 million versus $20 million in the second quarter of 2015. That brings the interest expense for the first half of the year to $45 million versus $41 million for the same period in 2015. For 2016, we continue to expect interest expense to be approximately $95 million, up from 2015 due to lower cash balances resulting from our capital deployment activities, which I'll cover in just a minute. 
We continue to expect free cash flow this year to look similar to 2015, but more weighted to the latter part of the year. At the end of the quarter, our balance sheet reflects the cash balance of $1.9 billion and a net debt position of $1.5 billion, both essentially unchanged from the end of the first quarter. Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we had $500 million of fixed rate notes mature and we're in the process of refinancing that debt as we speak. We intend to replace that debt and raise an additional $500 million for general corporate purposes to include share repurchases. 
Our effective tax rate was 27.7% for the quarter. This was lower than our original expectation as we adopted a new accounting standard that altered the accounting for tax benefits associated with our stock options and restricted stock. 
In a nutshell, these tax benefits are now treated as a permanent benefit that impact our effective tax rate. In the second quarter, this change reduced our effective tax rate by approximately 140 basis points. We're at a rate of 28.8% year-to-date, and we're now targeting a full year rate right around 29%. 
On the capital deployment front, in the second quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million shares, bringing us to just under 9 million shares in the first half of 2016 for almost $1.2 billion. In total, when combined with the dividends we paid through the first 6 months of the year, we spent $1.6 billion in shareholder friendly capital deployment, more than 2x our free cash flow for the first half. 
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn it back over to you for the Q&A.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the color on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with the used invento
componenttext: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the color on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with the used inventory that's out there and the 650? And then what you saw regionally. Did North America hold in there pretty well?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used airplan
componenttext: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used airplanes in the market. We simply do not see them. If I count serial numbers, we have 14 on the market right now with 1 pending transaction. We have 186 in service, so that equates to 7.5 of the fleet. That is well below the 10% used to in-service ratio. So that's rather typical. And by the way, we have long anticipated the emergence of a 650 used market. So in my mind, there should be no surprise. I would also note that we have seen minimal impact with a few customers choosing the near term availability rather than wait. So from my perspective, based on the facts and the data, we're quite comfortable that, that used market is appropriate and acting in a rational and typical sort of way. So 650, so if you talk about by model, the 650 demand remains quite active. In our submarkets, subsections of the market, the 450 and 550 are, as we anticipated, during this period of transition to the 500 and 600, complicated the touch by competitor's overproduction. By the way, I might tell you that the 500 and 600 positions are sold to a lot of -- a lot of those positions are sold in '16 and '17. So we like how all of that is shaping up. And with respect to the geographic distribution, about 50% of the orders were North America and I think the rest split between Mid East, Asia-Pacific, Europe and South America, in that order. Okay?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to switch to Marine for a moment, Phebe. You've got -- you guided for us earlier, but you have a lot going on there. You've got the Block IV pricing going up. There's growth in ORP funding. When would we start to see some real improvement in sales from all of these positives?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been experiencing that improvement, but when we look at the Navy's plan to continue with the Gulfstream or the Virginia class deliveries as well as our replacement, we see that we get some real nice ignition starting in '19 when we have long l
componenttext: Well, we've been experiencing that improvement, but when we look at the Navy's plan to continue with the Gulfstream or the Virginia class deliveries as well as our replacement, we see that we get some real nice ignition starting in '19 when we have long lead delivery how we're anticipating based on the Navy plan, long lead delivery in '19. But let's not forget, this has been a very nice steady quarter-over-quarter performance.

componenttext: True. And how would the TAOX factor in? And does that impact NASSCO's margins later through this year and next year to win there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the TAOX, let's remember that, that -- our award was for 1 ship and multiple I think with 5 options subject to the request, authorization and appropriation, right? So those orders are right in our wheel house and we ought to be able to perform very nic
componenttext: So the TAOX, let's remember that, that -- our award was for 1 ship and multiple I think with 5 options subject to the request, authorization and appropriation, right? So those orders are right in our wheel house and we ought to be able to perform very nicely on those. And it positions us well for the 17 ships in the Navy contract. It was an unusual award, but there were no surprises and I think from -- it was an unusual contracting process, but from my point of view, there were no surprises because it sort of lined up with who does what well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, you talked a lot about the earnings and the revenue for the year. In the past, you've talked about free cash flow conversion relative to last year. So now with a higher net income, should we still see a similar conversion? And somewhat related, we
componenttext: Phebe, you talked a lot about the earnings and the revenue for the year. In the past, you've talked about free cash flow conversion relative to last year. So now with a higher net income, should we still see a similar conversion? And somewhat related, we knew you were going to be eating into those international combat advances, but really, what should that advances line look like when we get to the end of the year on the balance sheet?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, so as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we
componenttext: Sam, so as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we had last year from a timing standpoint. As it relates to the advances, we'll continue to draw down on those. So you'll see that balance -- you've seen it come down throughout the first half of the year and we'll see that continue as we continue to make progress on the production side of those contracts through the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But coming down at the same rate?
componenttext: But coming down at the same rate?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have the exact specifics on that, we can perhaps talk after the call on that, but directionally, yes, we'll see it continue to come down.
componenttext: I don't have the exact specifics on that, we can perhaps talk after the call on that, but directionally, yes, we'll see it continue to come down.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Doug Harned of Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Doug Harned of Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the margin situation of Gulfstream. I mean, the margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're go
componenttext: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the margin situation of Gulfstream. I mean, the margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're going through a transition to the new programs, you have lower rate on the 450 and 550. And when you roll that forward, do you expect -- if you have to take rate down, perhaps even more on the 450 and 550, can you keep that margin level through the product transition?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but the margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out, they're driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the 65
componenttext: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but the margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out, they're driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the 650's nice contribution. So when I think about that, that and our performance on service has been quite nice through the course of the year. So I have a great deal of confidence that we can continue to maintain our profitability as we go through. We'll have to modify it somewhat, but with our profitability going through this transition period.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?
componenttext: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've pretty much planned in the rates on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see anymore reduction on the 450. In the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look, our job is to keep earnings up as high as possibl
componenttext: Well, we've pretty much planned in the rates on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see anymore reduction on the 450. In the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look, our job is to keep earnings up as high as possible during this transition period and manage our margins. We're going to continue to do that. I think we've demonstrated that track record in the last 6 quarters and we're going to continue going forward.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Howard Rubel of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Howard Rubel of Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, Phebe, I have a clarification. I think you said 500, 600 sold in '16 and '17. Did you mean that you're largely sold out in '17 and '18?
componenttext: First, Phebe, I have a clarification. I think you said 500, 600 sold in '16 and '17. Did you mean that you're largely sold out in '17 and '18?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm sorry if I wasn't clear on that. The 650 is sold out in its entirety through the first quarter -- or through 2016 and also in its entirety in 2017. So when we look at the order activity on the 500 and 600, what I'm saying is, is that our expectat
componenttext: Yes. I'm sorry if I wasn't clear on that. The 650 is sold out in its entirety through the first quarter -- or through 2016 and also in its entirety in 2017. So when we look at the order activity on the 500 and 600, what I'm saying is, is that our expectations for entering into service would remain the same. We have -- in that projection, we have sold an awful lot of our both of those 500s and 600s, so that positions us very well, I think.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm sorry, again, so '17 and '18 for the 500 and 600 are largely sold, is that how I'm hearing this?
componenttext: So I'm sorry, again, so '17 and '18 for the 500 and 600 are largely sold, is that how I'm hearing this?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've had a lot of sales.
componenttext: Yes, we've had a lot of sales.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow this. It sounds like though there were some adjustments to the large cabin delivery schedule. Could you articulate where you are for this year? And I guess you probably won't. And then you can maybe if you can address some elements
componenttext: And then just to follow this. It sounds like though there were some adjustments to the large cabin delivery schedule. Could you articulate where you are for this year? And I guess you probably won't. And then you can maybe if you can address some elements of how you're thinking about '17?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't want to get into '17 at the moment, because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year ha
componenttext: So I don't want to get into '17 at the moment, because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year have not changed. So we've kept them the same as when we set this plan. Revenue is impacted in '16 by a couple of factors. 1, we have 1 less green airplane, I think it's the 280, and 6 fewer completions. We're moving these completions from this year into next, largely because of customer preferences on when they want to take the plane. And then we got a mix of other smaller puts and takes.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Gursky of Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the 500 and the 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event a few years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of barbelled, you take some at the beginning. We'd have
componenttext: Just to follow up on the 500 and the 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event a few years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of barbelled, you take some at the beginning. We'd have a lull until you got closer to the entry into service of the aircraft. Wondering if that's still the way that you're thinking about that? And at what point, historically, do you see the second end of that barbell begin to pick up? Meaning, when might we see some more orders for the 500 and 600 begin to come in relative to the entry into service? How much before entry into service we see that pick back up?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't have perfect clarity about the precise timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectation, building on the good sales we've had heretofore, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.
componenttext: So I don't have perfect clarity about the precise timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectation, building on the good sales we've had heretofore, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, can you comment on the capital deployment strategy and where your head is currently in terms of M&A? The market's gotten richer or cheaper and property availability has gotten better or worse? And also the repurchase slowdown, is there anything to
componenttext: Phebe, can you comment on the capital deployment strategy and where your head is currently in terms of M&A? The market's gotten richer or cheaper and property availability has gotten better or worse? And also the repurchase slowdown, is there anything to read there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on M&A, I really don't have any update for you, but if and when we do something, we'll let you know. We'll get back to  you. Jason, do you want to talk through the share repo?
componenttext: Yes. So on M&A, I really don't have any update for you, but if and when we do something, we'll let you know. We'll get back to  you. Jason, do you want to talk through the share repo?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives and our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second q
componenttext: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives and our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second quarter and feel like by the balance of the first half of the year, we're right on track and doing exactly what we had hoped to do. We deployed, as I said, 2x our free cash flow on share repurchase and dividends. So I don't think you should see that as a signal of any directional shift for us at any time.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the full-year return of capital is still targeted to be 100% in net income though?
componenttext: So the full-year return of capital is still targeted to be 100% in net income though?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclays.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not your cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reduction actions and furloughs, I didn't know i
componenttext: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not your cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reduction actions and furloughs, I didn't know if any of that changed from what you initially planned on. And then 1 for Jason. Just on the FX front, I mean, you've called out the U.K. impact. I think you've got a little bit of Swiss impact as well. Should we be -- what should we be thinking of in terms of forward impacts if currencies stay where they are? Are there any transactional FX exposures that we should be aware of going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, as I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't the same in each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really it's cost management, cost reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity
componenttext: Yes. So look, as I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't the same in each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really it's cost management, cost reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity to estimate the goodness that you can achieve until you're really in the moment, right? So we're continuing to manage our cost. I think we've got more way to go. And then at the same time, by the way, we've got to continue to improve the 650 and 280 operating margins, which we will do and are doing. And then we've got to ensure that 400 and 500 -- or 450 and 500 maintain their profitability. And so I think that, that will look very nice on track, particularly with respect to the latter.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, you can think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated gui
componenttext: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, you can think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated guidance that Phebe walked you through earlier was actually predicated on the latest rates we have at hand projected to the balance of the year. So that is the latest look at the impact and it's not -- I wouldn't call it material through the balance of the year, but we also don't necessarily take a bet on rates moving further one way or another. So if there is a further movement in the second half, we would obviously tell you about that and it could have an upside or a downside impact to that guidance. The last thing I would say is that there's no, absolutely 0, from our perspective transactional exposure. This is all strictly, as we've discussed before, the translation for U.S. dollar reporting. Everything from a transactional perspective is hedged and has been working effectively up to this point.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I was wondering if you could just give us a quick update where we stand on the Ohio class program. In terms of what's going on actually you had Electric Boat and then what you're looking for over the next coming quarters?
componenttext: Phebe, I was wondering if you could just give us a quick update where we stand on the Ohio class program. In terms of what's going on actually you had Electric Boat and then what you're looking for over the next coming quarters?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and process development plan. And think about that as the detailed design an
componenttext: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and process development plan. And think about that as the detailed design and long lead material portion of the procurement process. So the Navy is reviewing that in the moment. I think their plan is to get back to us sometime late summer or early fall. But we are -- that's kind of their call in terms of the cadence of the timing. But that will provide and should provide, depending when we close on that, some upside in this year. And then again, as we've talked before, this is a very strong growth engine for us over time.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year? And I think at one point you said you'd rather takedown production than take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G5
componenttext: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year? And I think at one point you said you'd rather takedown production than take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G500?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got
componenttext: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got to bring down the production on the 450, 550, while ramping up the production of the 500 and 600. The ease of this is somewhat benefited, it somewhat benefits from the fact that these 2 sets of airplanes are built in completely different facilities. So if you're suggesting that we have a gap, it's not an altogether bad thing, as long as we stay on schedule for our deliveries in the 400 -- or 500 and 600, which I see no reason why we can't at the moment. But we're in a good shape for next year on the 450, 550. We've got a little ways more to go. And then we'll set the production rates for the 500 and 600 as we move forward. So does that get to the essence of your question?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful.
componenttext: That's helpful.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could tell us, maybe Jason, of the shortfall in cash flow, free cash flow, relative to net income this year, maybe in kind of qualitative terms, how much of that is related to the construction of flight test articles for G500 and 60
componenttext: I was wondering if you could tell us, maybe Jason, of the shortfall in cash flow, free cash flow, relative to net income this year, maybe in kind of qualitative terms, how much of that is related to the construction of flight test articles for G500 and 600? And do all those flight test articles go to customers and so did all of those cost go into inventory?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually they go into long-term product design use for the customers. I would say that the outsize -- from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, is
componenttext: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually they go into long-term product design use for the customers. I would say that the outsize -- from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, is really more about the international program advances being drawn down. There's some impact on, not so much the flight test aircraft impact at Gulfstream so much as just inventory build toward production, but that's the minor share. The larger share really is about the international advanced draw down.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to pursue, you had 4 used sales in Gulfstream. Could you give us the revenues and approximate earnings? And I would assume that, that would have deflated the margin you reported as high as it was. So when you go to the second half and you have hi
componenttext: I wanted to pursue, you had 4 used sales in Gulfstream. Could you give us the revenues and approximate earnings? And I would assume that, that would have deflated the margin you reported as high as it was. So when you go to the second half and you have higher revenues, why does the margin be somewhat less than what it was this quarter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, I'll take that. The revenues for the quarter were right around $40 million, I believe, is the number for preowned. And as is typical, it's right around breakeven, maybe $1 million or $2 million loss associated with those, which is pretty typica
componenttext: So George, I'll take that. The revenues for the quarter were right around $40 million, I believe, is the number for preowned. And as is typical, it's right around breakeven, maybe $1 million or $2 million loss associated with those, which is pretty typical. If I understand your question, for the balance of the year, we do have profiled, as we've talked about before, an expectation of additional preowned coming into inventory and being sold, which actually is consistent with the point Phebe made before with a little bit of a downtick in margins, particularly in the third quarter. So I think those are consistent, unless I misunderstood your question about the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's right, Jason. I just thought that to deliver 4 used planes in subsequent quarters, you're probably not going do that much, maybe you will. So I was kind of figuring the used planes would be less, so you got a little less pressure on the p
componenttext: No. I think it's right, Jason. I just thought that to deliver 4 used planes in subsequent quarters, you're probably not going do that much, maybe you will. So I was kind of figuring the used planes would be less, so you got a little less pressure on the profits and you got higher revenues. You've got higher revenue.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little bit more color on that. The planes in the quarter, there were 4 of them, but the mix of them, they were pretty modest in terms of revenue per unit. So that's not the assumption necessarily going forward. There are a lot of different mix in there
componenttext: A little bit more color on that. The planes in the quarter, there were 4 of them, but the mix of them, they were pretty modest in terms of revenue per unit. So that's not the assumption necessarily going forward. There are a lot of different mix in there in terms of inventory that we take in.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so think about it this way, George, we sold 4 in the quarter, which you know. We took in 3 and have sold 1. So today, we have 2 in inventory. But remember that the margin impact from -- can vary depending on the aircraft itself.
componenttext: Yes, so think about it this way, George, we sold 4 in the quarter, which you know. We took in 3 and have sold 1. So today, we have 2 in inventory. But remember that the margin impact from -- can vary depending on the aircraft itself.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a good answer. And one quick one. Combat margin is usually the biggest in the fourth quarter and yet your guidance is implying the second half won't be as good as the first half. So if you had a little explanation on that?
componenttext: Okay. That's a good answer. And one quick one. Combat margin is usually the biggest in the fourth quarter and yet your guidance is implying the second half won't be as good as the first half. So if you had a little explanation on that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are in the third and, more importantly, in the fourth quarter beginning to move from our -- as the domestic land forces contract, some of those begin to taper down, we are increasing our international production. So we have -- we've got -- that
componenttext: Yes. So we are in the third and, more importantly, in the fourth quarter beginning to move from our -- as the domestic land forces contract, some of those begin to taper down, we are increasing our international production. So we have -- we've got -- that's really the margin pressure, it's simply a question of mix. As long as operating performance is good, these guys have done very well, but they've got to come down their learning curves, right?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Hunter Keay of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Hunter Keay of Wolfe Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, can you give us any color on the customer mix or geography and all those mid-cabins in the quarter that you sold? And was that activity inline with your expectations on a dollar-based book-to-bill basis? Or would you say this slightly surprised of
componenttext: Phebe, can you give us any color on the customer mix or geography and all those mid-cabins in the quarter that you sold? And was that activity inline with your expectations on a dollar-based book-to-bill basis? Or would you say this slightly surprised of the upside and sort of to that, can you talk about how wait times on the mids change in the quarter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I understand your question properly, we had -- our sales on the 280 were a little different or a little better than we had anticipated. And I think that's just reflecting the strength of the North American market. So with respect to wait times, and
componenttext: So if I understand your question properly, we had -- our sales on the 280 were a little different or a little better than we had anticipated. And I think that's just reflecting the strength of the North American market. So with respect to wait times, and let me give you this opportunity or take this opportunity to give you a little bit of color on the wait times. On the G650 and 50ER, we're about 24 months; 550 and 450, 9 to 12, no change; 280, 9 to 12; and the 150, we've got onsies and twosies left to sell there. So the first available there is a year from now.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the 280, better-than-expected that wasn't just timing, that was actually just maybe you just won a few more awards that could have gone either way?
componenttext: Okay. So on the 280, better-than-expected that wasn't just timing, that was actually just maybe you just won a few more awards that could have gone either way?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that that's right. That's always the case, right? We understand our customers needs, but the order in which they want to execute replacement of their fleet will kind of depend on their imminent needs for their -- imminent needs for the missio
componenttext: Yes. I think that that's right. That's always the case, right? We understand our customers needs, but the order in which they want to execute replacement of their fleet will kind of depend on their imminent needs for their -- imminent needs for the mission that a particular airplane serves. So the good news is, they're selling well, the 280s, but it does impact the bill.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski of Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski of Drexel Hamilton.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I guess, I'll ask you one on the Navy service program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial[ph] recapitalization. And I know you have some pote
componenttext: Phebe, I guess, I'll ask you one on the Navy service program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial[ph] recapitalization. And I know you have some potential CapEx, bills to pay, as you think about what would the right rates are going to be. So how you decide on your CapEx profile there at Marine, given kind of the sizable bills that Navy is going to have to pay and if they can pay those bills are not?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's often chatter when we -- and its been true from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a nuc
componenttext: Well, there's often chatter when we -- and its been true from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a nuclear deterrent, they've got to build this submarine. So that's #1, that's my view. And I think that that's supported by many people in the government on both the executive and the congressional side. So I wouldn't say that, that Democratic some chatter in the system suggests they're walking away from this requirement. So I think in terms of the -- the Navy has budgeted here a revenue flow to us that we can easily accommodate the CapEx and the other improvements that we have going forward in terms of the ability to build these. I might also tell you that we've been spending CapEx over the last few years to position ourselves, particularly at the quantum point on the Ohio replacement. So we work very carefully with our Navy customer to determine what they need, what we need, the funding allocation, who's responsible for what and we're certainly not going to get caught long.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think alternatively you keep the Virginia rate at 2 per year?
componenttext: Do you think alternatively you keep the Virginia rate at 2 per year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff VP for Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to s
componenttext:
Thank you, Candace, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' second quarter conference call. As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than the y
componenttext:
Thank you, Erin, and good morning. As you may observe from our press release, we enjoyed a very good second quarter with revenue of $7.67 billion and net earnings of $758 million. We reported EPS of $2.44 per diluted share, $0.17 a share better than the year ago quarter. We were also $0.13 a share better than consensus. 
With respect to consensus, it would appear that the sell side anticipated about $200 million more revenue, lower margin and a somewhat higher tax rate. Compared to consensus, we had about $30 million more in operating earnings on higher margins, $10 million less in taxes resulting in about $40 million more in net earnings. The big driver in the quarter was the operational performance. Compared to the year ago quarter, revenue of $7.67 billion was $217 million lower. However, earnings of $758 million were up $6 million on a 30 basis point improvement in operating margin and 140 basis point lower effective tax rate. 
I should note that our earnings in the year ago quarter included a gain on the sale of our commercial cyber business. Excluding that gain, there is a 60-basis-point improvement in operating margins. Sequentially, revenue was down $59 million or less than 1% and earnings from continuing operations were up $28 million on a 40 basis point improvement in operating margins and a lower effective tax rate. 
Let me turn briefly to the first half of 2016 and compare it to the first half of '15. Revenue was down 1.8% against the first half of 2015. On the other hand, operating earnings were up $15 million. Operating margins were 30 basis points better. Earnings from continuing operations were up $20 million, EPS was $0.36 better. 
In short, we're off to a good start ahead of both our internal plan and external expectations. That leads quite naturally to the guidance increase reflected in the press release. I'll provide additional color on that guidance shortly. But first let me give you some perspective on the segment reporting for the quarter and for the half. I'll then conclude with some comments on the outlook for each segment for the remainder of the year and wrap that into our EPS guidance. 
First, Aerospace. Aerospace had a very good quarter. Revenue of $2.13 billion was $124 million lower than the year-ago quarter. Operating earnings of $434 million were only $5 million less on a 90 basis point improvement in operating margins. Importantly, on a sequential basis, revenue was up $147 million or 7.4% and operating earnings were up $23 million or 5.6%. For the first half, revenue at $4.12 billion is off $245 million against last year, reflecting planned production cuts to the 450 and the 550, offset in part by increased delivery of the 650. However, earnings at $845 million are only $25 million or off only $25 million on a 60 basis point improvement in margin. In short, at $845 million in operating earnings for the first half of the year, we are well positioned to achieve or exceed our earning goal for the year. 
By the way, recall that last year, we told you that we had in Q1 a positive supply of settlement. After that contribution, earnings would actually have been up this year. So let me give you some commentary about order activity in the quarter and then some observations about the current state of the market. First, on a numerical unit basis, we had 50% more orders than we did in the first quarter. However, the mix was not as advantageous. In other words, think about it this way, we sold more mid-cabin in the quarter than in the first quarter. So the dollar-based book-to-bill was not much better, about 1/3 of our orders in the quarter were mid-cabin. Activity and interest level were good throughout the quarter, but at the end of the quarter, when many transactions typically close, activity almost ceased as a result of the events associated with the Brexit vote. However, those customers did not go away and are continuing to pursue transactions with us this quarter. 
We are quite optimistic regarding third quarter sales activity. Active prospects are very good, better than at any time in the year. The U.S. jobs report earlier this month, slightly improved economic stories in the U.S. and, to a lesser extent, in Europe, coupled with the quick market recovery from the initial Brexit vote reaction seem to have accelerated the activity level on our prospects. We fully expect a good third quarter and second half from an order perspective. 
You may recall that the G500 made its first flight in the second quarter last year. This month, it made its international debut at the Farnborough Airshow. T4, that's the fourth test article, made the flight from Savannah to Farnborough in 6 hours and 55 minutes, traveling at a steady 0.9 Mach. Flight test is going very well and we are on or somewhat ahead of schedule. We look forward to the first flight of the G600 late this year. 
Let's take a look at Combat. They had a very solid quarter. Revenue was $1.32 billion, $93 million less than the second quarter last year. However, a 60 basis point improvement in operating margins resulted in a modest $7 million increase in operating earnings over the year ago quarter. All in all, very good operating leverage and an outstanding 16.7%. 
On a sequential basis, revenue was up $42 million or 3.3% and operating earnings were up $2 million, about 1%. For the first half, revenue was down $183 million or 6.6% against the first half of 2015. Operating earnings, on the other hand, were up $6 million on a 130 basis point margin expansion, pretty impressive operating performance. 
Work is progressing quite well on our international orders, with prototypes in production for both our AJAX Program and our Canadian Mideast contract. We were also awarded a contract to begin fast yielding [ph] of the Upgun Stryker. 
With respect to the Marine group, revenue of $1.99 billion was $14 million lower than Q2 a year ago. Operating earnings were off $6 million against the year-ago quarter and operating margins were off 20 basis points. On a sequential basis, revenue was down $144 million due to timing on summary material purchases. Operating earnings were down $11 million, resulting in a modest 10 basis point improvement in operating margin. 
For the first half, revenue of $4.1 billion was up $174 million or 4.4% against the first half of '15. Operating earnings were essentially the same on somewhat lower margins. Marine Systems has been a compelling growth story for us and will continue to be so. We have some work to do on margins in the second half. 
Turning to IS&T, that group continues to do well. Revenue of $2.2 billion and operating earnings of $244 million were up against the year ago quarter, $14 million and $7 million, respectively. There was a 20 basis point improvement in operating margin, which was particularly impressive when one considers that the sale of the commercial cyber product business contributed 100 basis points of margin in the year ago quarter. Sequentially, revenue was lower by $104 million, but operating earnings were down only $4 million, or 1.6% on a 30 basis point improvement in margin. This 10.9% margin is the strongest in nearly 5 years. 
The story for the first half is much the same, revenue was down $23 million, 0.5%, and operating earnings were up $38 million or 8.4% on a 90 basis point improvement of margin. So once again, very strong operating leverage. 
This group also tells a story about building the backlog through the first half. Book-to-bill at about 1.3, which marks the eighth quarter in the last 10 quarters the group has achieved a book-to-bill equal to or greater than 1 to 1. In short, we believe all this leaves us poised for a good second half. 
So turning to guidance. Let me provide you some guidance for the year for each segment and then compare it to what we told you in January and then wrap it up into our EPS guidance. 
For Aerospace. Our guidance was to expect revenue somewhat lower than 2015 and margins somewhat higher than 2015, leading to flat operating earnings. We now expect to be between $8.5 billion and $8.6 billion of revenue, with margins slightly above 20%. This implies a slight pressure on margins in the second half, particularly in the third quarter. This will result in operating earnings the same as last year, even slightly better. Despite all the hand wringing by some, these 2 businesses will continue to perform well. 
So for Combat Systems, our previous guidance was to expect revenue of approximately $5.8 billion and margins in the mid-15% area. We now expect revenue of somewhat over $5.7 billion and margins at 16% to 16.1%. Revenue will see strong uplift in the fourth quarter. The difference in revenue guidance is simply from timing. 
For the Marine group, we previously guided to revenue of $8 billion and margins in the mid-9% range. We now expect revenue to be between $8.1 billion and $8.2 billion and margins around 9.2%. 
For IS&T, we guided to revenue of about $9 billion and margins approaching double digits. It now appears that our revenue guidance was good, with slight upward pressure and that operating margins will be somewhat better than 10.5% for the year. 
So all of this rolls up into revenue for GD of about $31.5 billion, operating margins of 13.7% to 13.8%, net income somewhat more than the $3 billion and the return on sales of around 9.6%. Compared to our initial guidance, we will have somewhat lower revenue but higher operating income on higher margins, a somewhat lower tax rate and a lower share count, which permits us to increase our EPS guidance to $9.70. To help you further, our original EPS guidance was $9.20 per share. The $0.50 difference is $0.24 from operations, $0.09 from a lower tax rate and $0.17 from share repurchases. If you think about the progression for the remainder of the year, third quarter should be somewhat weaker than the second, but much like the first, followed by a very strong fourth quarter. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Jason Aiken, our CFO.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll start with an update to an issue that we've been addressing since last year and that's the impact we're seeing from foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation. This continues to be focused in our Combat Systems group. And when you compare that group's results to the first half of 2016 to the similar period a year ago, our 2016 revenue would have been higher by approximately $75 million had the exchange rates that prevailed in the first half of 2015, remained in effect this year. And for the company as a whole, revenue would have been a little over $100 million higher. 
Moving down the income statement. Our net interest expense in the quarter was $23 million versus $20 million in the second quarter of 2015. That brings the interest expense for the first half of the year to $45 million versus $41 million for the same period in 2015. For 2016, we continue to expect interest expense to be approximately $95 million, up from 2015 due to lower cash balances resulting from our capital deployment activities, which I'll cover in just a minute. 
We continue to expect free cash flow this year to look similar to 2015, but more weighted to the latter part of the year. At the end of the quarter, our balance sheet reflects the cash balance of $1.9 billion and a net debt position of $1.5 billion, both essentially unchanged from the end of the first quarter. Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we had $500 million of fixed rate notes mature and we're in the process of refinancing that debt as we speak. We intend to replace that debt and raise an additional $500 million for general corporate purposes to include share repurchases. 
Our effective tax rate was 27.7% for the quarter. This was lower than our original expectation as we adopted a new accounting standard that altered the accounting for tax benefits associated with our stock options and restricted stock. 
In a nutshell, these tax benefits are now treated as a permanent benefit that impact our effective tax rate. In the second quarter, this change reduced our effective tax rate by approximately 140 basis points. We're at a rate of 28.8% year-to-date, and we're now targeting a full year rate right around 29%. 
On the capital deployment front, in the second quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million shares, bringing us to just under 9 million shares in the first half of 2016 for almost $1.2 billion. In total, when combined with the dividends we paid through the first 6 months of the year, we spent $1.6 billion in shareholder friendly capital deployment, more than 2x our free cash flow for the first half. 
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn it back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the color on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with the used invento
componenttext: Phebe, maybe -- thanks for all the color on Gulfstream, but maybe just a little bit more color on the large-cabin market and how you saw it evolve in Q2, both from a used inventory perspective, how you're competing on the 450 and 550 with the used inventory that's out there and the 650? And then what you saw regionally. Did North America hold in there pretty well?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used airplan
componenttext: Yes. So I think I gave you a pretty robust response in my remarks, but let me parse this -- our market in a couple of ways. First, let's talk about the 650 preowned market. So I've seen some folks saying there's going to be 20 or there are 21 used airplanes in the market. We simply do not see them. If I count serial numbers, we have 14 on the market right now with 1 pending transaction. We have 186 in service, so that equates to 7.5 of the fleet. That is well below the 10% used to in-service ratio. So that's rather typical. And by the way, we have long anticipated the emergence of a 650 used market. So in my mind, there should be no surprise. I would also note that we have seen minimal impact with a few customers choosing the near term availability rather than wait. So from my perspective, based on the facts and the data, we're quite comfortable that, that used market is appropriate and acting in a rational and typical sort of way. So 650, so if you talk about by model, the 650 demand remains quite active. In our submarkets, subsections of the market, the 450 and 550 are, as we anticipated, during this period of transition to the 500 and 600, complicated the touch by competitor's overproduction. By the way, I might tell you that the 500 and 600 positions are sold to a lot of -- a lot of those positions are sold in '16 and '17. So we like how all of that is shaping up. And with respect to the geographic distribution, about 50% of the orders were North America and I think the rest split between Mid East, Asia-Pacific, Europe and South America, in that order. Okay?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Robert Spingarn of Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Robert Spingarn of Crdit Suisse.
