componenttext: I wanted to switch to Marine for a moment, Phebe. You've got -- you guided for us earlier, but you have a lot going on there. You've got the Block IV pricing going up. There's growth in ORP funding. When would we start to see some real improvement in sales from all of these positives?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Well, we've been experiencing that improvement, but when we look at the Navy's plan to continue with the Gulfstream or the Virginia class deliveries as well as our replacement, we see that we get some real nice ignition starting in '19 when we have long lead delivery how we're anticipating based on the Navy plan, long lead delivery in '19. But let's not forget, this has been a very nice steady quarter-over-quarter performance.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: True. And how would the TAOX factor in? And does that impact NASSCO's margins later through this year and next year to win there?

componenttextpreview: So the TAOX, let's remember that, that -- our award was for 1 ship and multiple I think with 5 options subject to the request, authorization and appropriation, right? So those orders are right in our wheel house and we ought to be able to perform very nic
componenttext: So the TAOX, let's remember that, that -- our award was for 1 ship and multiple I think with 5 options subject to the request, authorization and appropriation, right? So those orders are right in our wheel house and we ought to be able to perform very nicely on those. And it positions us well for the 17 ships in the Navy contract. It was an unusual award, but there were no surprises and I think from -- it was an unusual contracting process, but from my point of view, there were no surprises because it sort of lined up with who does what well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, you talked a lot about the earnings and the revenue for the year. In the past, you've talked about free cash flow conversion relative to last year. So now with a higher net income, should we still see a similar conversion? And somewhat related, we
componenttext: Phebe, you talked a lot about the earnings and the revenue for the year. In the past, you've talked about free cash flow conversion relative to last year. So now with a higher net income, should we still see a similar conversion? And somewhat related, we knew you were going to be eating into those international combat advances, but really, what should that advances line look like when we get to the end of the year on the balance sheet?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, so as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we
componenttext: Sam, so as I addressed in my remarks, we do continue to see full year free cash flow for this year looking similar to what we had last year. Although as I said, a little bit inverted towards the second half of the year, slightly different profile than we had last year from a timing standpoint. As it relates to the advances, we'll continue to draw down on those. So you'll see that balance -- you've seen it come down throughout the first half of the year and we'll see that continue as we continue to make progress on the production side of those contracts through the balance of the year.

componenttextpreview: But coming down at the same rate?
componenttext: But coming down at the same rate?

componenttext: I don't have the exact specifics on that, we can perhaps talk after the call on that, but directionally, yes, we'll see it continue to come down.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Doug Harned of Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Doug Harned of Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the margin situation of Gulfstream. I mean, the margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're go
componenttext: I wanted to try and understand a little bit of the margin situation of Gulfstream. I mean, the margins have been great at around 20% level, even with declining productions. So can you talk a little bit about what's enabled you to achieve that as you're going through a transition to the new programs, you have lower rate on the 450 and 550. And when you roll that forward, do you expect -- if you have to take rate down, perhaps even more on the 450 and 550, can you keep that margin level through the product transition?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but the margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out, they're driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the 65
componenttext: Well, let's talk about this year and I don't want to get into too much specificity in '17 and '18, but the margins are driven by -- and this is true year in and year out, they're driven by our managing of cost and our cost reductions in addition to the 650's nice contribution. So when I think about that, that and our performance on service has been quite nice through the course of the year. So I have a great deal of confidence that we can continue to maintain our profitability as we go through. We'll have to modify it somewhat, but with our profitability going through this transition period.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?
componenttext: And that is even as you take rates down and you, in theory, would lose some operating leverage?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've pretty much planned in the rates on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see any more reduction on the 450. In the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look, our job is to keep earnings up as high as possib
componenttext: Well, we've pretty much planned in the rates on the 450. I don't see any more reductions like that. I don't see any more reduction on the 450. In the 550, we see very minimal changes going forward. So look, our job is to keep earnings up as high as possible during this transition period and manage our margins. We're going to continue to do that. I think we've demonstrated that track record in the last 6 quarters and we're going to continue going forward.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Howard Rubel of Jefferies.

componenttext: Yes. I'm sorry if I wasn't clear on that. The 650 is sold out in its entirety through the first quarter -- or through 2016 and also in its entirety in 2017. So when we look at the order activity on the 500 and 600, what I'm saying is, is that our expectations for entering into service would remain the same. We have -- in that projection, we have sold an awful lot of our both of those 500s and 600s, so that positions us very well, I think.

componenttext: So I'm sorry, again, so '17 and '18 for the 500 and 600 are largely sold, is that how I'm hearing this?

componenttext: And then just to follow this. It sounds like though there were some adjustments to the large cabin delivery schedule. Could you articulate where you are for this year? And I guess you probably won't. And then you can maybe if you can address some elements of how you're thinking about '17?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't want to get into '17 at the moment, because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year ha
componenttext: So I don't want to get into '17 at the moment, because as you know, we provide that to you all in the fourth quarter of the '16 call by tradition. So that said, let me give you some color on where we are in the moment. First, production rates this year have not changed. So we've kept them the same as when we set this plan. Revenue is impacted in '16 by a couple of factors. 1, we have 1 less green airplane, I think it's the 280, and 6 fewer completions. We're moving these completions from this year into next, largely because of customer preferences on when they want to take the plane. And then we got a mix of other smaller puts and takes.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Gursky of Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the 500 and the 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event a few years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of barbelled, you take some at the beginning. We'd have
componenttext: Just to follow up on the 500 and the 600 really quickly. I think at the launch event a few years ago, you suggested that the book-to-bill or the bookings that you take on that aircraft would be kind of barbelled, you take some at the beginning. We'd have a lull until you got closer to the entry into service of the aircraft. Wondering if that's still the way that you're thinking about that? And at what point, historically, do you see the second end of that barbell begin to pick up? Meaning, when might we see some more orders for the 500 and 600 begin to come in relative to the entry into service? How much before entry into service we see that pick back up?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't have perfect clarity about the precise timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectation, building on the good sales we've had heretofore, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.
componenttext: So I don't have perfect clarity about the precise timing of when orders will pick up. But it's our expectation, building on the good sales we've had heretofore, that the closer these airplanes are to entry into service, our sales will pick up.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, can you comment on the capital deployment strategy and where your head is currently in terms of M&A? The market's gotten richer or cheaper and property availability has gotten better or worse? And also the repurchase slowdown, is there anything to
componenttext: Phebe, can you comment on the capital deployment strategy and where your head is currently in terms of M&A? The market's gotten richer or cheaper and property availability has gotten better or worse? And also the repurchase slowdown, is there anything to read there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on M&A, I really don't have any update for you, but if and when we do something, we'll let you know. We'll get back to  you. Jason, do you want to talk through the share repo?
componenttext: Yes. So on M&A, I really don't have any update for you, but if and when we do something, we'll let you know. We'll get back to  you. Jason, do you want to talk through the share repo?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives and our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second q
componenttext: Yes. I think Myles, for the balance when you think about the year, our objectives and our targets for the year on deployment haven't changed. As you know, we were fairly on the active side in the first quarter of the year. And so we looked at the second quarter and feel like by the balance of the first half of the year, we're right on track and doing exactly what we had hoped to do. We deployed, as I said, 2x our free cash flow on share repurchase and dividends. So I don't think you should see that as a signal of any directional shift for us at any time.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the full-year return of capital is still targeted to be 100% in net income though?
componenttext: So the full-year return of capital is still targeted to be 100% in net income though?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Carter Copeland of Barclays.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not your cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reduction actions and furloughs, I didn't know i
componenttext: Just a clarification and a question. I know Phebe, you said the production plan didn't change, but I just wondered if you could clarify whether or not your cost plan changed at all. I know you had some cost reduction actions and furloughs, I didn't know if any of that changed from what you initially planned on. And then 1 for Jason. Just on the FX front, I mean, you've called out the U.K. impact. I think you've got a little bit of Swiss impact as well. Should we be -- what should we be thinking of in terms of forward impacts if currencies stay where they are? Are there any transactional FX exposures that we should be aware of going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, as I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't the same in each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really it's cost management, cost reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity
componenttext: Yes. So look, as I mentioned earlier, our margins at that level really aren't the same in each and every quarter. But the 650 is contributing and really it's cost management, cost reduction that's driving our margins. And so it's hard with perfect clarity to estimate the goodness that you can achieve until you're really in the moment, right? So we're continuing to manage our cost. I think we've got more way to go. And then at the same time, by the way, we've got to continue to improve the 650 and 280 operating margins, which we will do and are doing. And then we've got to ensure that 400 and 500 -- or 450 and 500 maintain their profitability. And so I think that, that will look very nice on track, particularly with respect to the latter.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, you can think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated gui
componenttext: So Carter, with respect to your foreign exchange question, you can think about our exposures this way in order of magnitude,  if you will, it's really Canadian dollars, euros, pounds and then Swiss francs sort of in terms of magnitude. But the updated guidance that Phebe walked you through earlier was actually predicated on the latest rates we have at hand projected to the balance of the year. So that is the latest look at the impact and it's not -- I wouldn't call it material through the balance of the year, but we also don't necessarily take a bet on rates moving further one way or another. So if there is a further movement in the second half, we would obviously tell you about that and it could have an upside or a downside impact to that guidance. The last thing I would say is that there's no, absolutely 0, from our perspective transactional exposure. This is all strictly, as we've discussed before, the translation for U.S. dollar reporting. Everything from a transactional perspective is hedged and has been working effectively up to this point.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I was wondering if you could just give us a quick update where we stand on the Ohio class program. In terms of what's going on actually you had Electric Boat and then what you're looking for over the next coming quarters?
componenttext: Phebe, I was wondering if you could just give us a quick update where we stand on the Ohio class program. In terms of what's going on actually you had Electric Boat and then what you're looking for over the next coming quarters?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and process development plan. And think about that as the detailed design an
componenttext: Yes. So if you've been following this, the Navy and Electric Boat have been active in a number of discussions. Most recently, we delivered our Ohio replacement integrated product and process development plan. And think about that as the detailed design and long lead material portion of the procurement process. So the Navy is reviewing that in the moment. I think their plan is to get back to us sometime late summer or early fall. But we are -- that's kind of their call in terms of the cadence of the timing. But that will provide and should provide, depending when we close on that, some upside in this year. And then again, as we've talked before, this is a very strong growth engine for us over time.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year? And I think at one point you said you'd rather takedown production than take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G5
componenttext: So Phebe, how far are the G450 and 550 sold into next year? And I think at one point you said you'd rather takedown production than take down price. How large is that period between when that backlog ends and when we might see initial deliveries of the G500?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got
componenttext: So I'm comfortable that we can manage this transition and we are in good shape to either we sold a fair number of the positions going into next year, particularly on the 450 and also on the 550. So the transition, the trick to the transition is we've got to bring down the production on the 450, 550, while ramping up the production of the 500 and 600. The ease of this is somewhat benefited, it somewhat benefits from the fact that these 2 sets of airplanes are built in completely different facilities. So if you're suggesting that we have a gap, it's not an altogether bad thing, as long as we stay on schedule for our deliveries in the 400 -- or 500 and 600, which I see no reason why we can't at the moment. But we're in a good shape for next year on the 450, 550. We've got a little ways more to go. And then we'll set the production rates for the 500 and 600 as we move forward. So does that get to the essence of your question?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful.
componenttext: That's helpful.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could tell us, maybe Jason, of the shortfall in cash flow, free cash flow, relative to net income this year, maybe in kind of qualitative terms, how much of that is related to the construction of flight test articles for G500 and 60
componenttext: I was wondering if you could tell us, maybe Jason, of the shortfall in cash flow, free cash flow, relative to net income this year, maybe in kind of qualitative terms, how much of that is related to the construction of flight test articles for G500 and 600? And do all those flight test articles go to customers and so did all of those cost go into inventory?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually they go into long-term product design use for the customers. I would say that the outsize -- from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, is
componenttext: So the flight test articles do go into inventory and they will eventually they go into long-term product design use for the customers. I would say that the outsize -- from a qualitative standpoint, the outsize, the impact on the cash flow differential, is really more about the international program advances being drawn down. There's some impact on, not so much the flight test aircraft impact at Gulfstream so much as just inventory build toward production, but that's the minor share. The larger share really is about the international advanced draw down.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to pursue, you had 4 used sales in Gulfstream. Could you give us the revenues and approximate earnings? And I would assume that, that would have deflated the margin you reported as high as it was. So when you go to the second half and you have hi
componenttext: I wanted to pursue, you had 4 used sales in Gulfstream. Could you give us the revenues and approximate earnings? And I would assume that, that would have deflated the margin you reported as high as it was. So when you go to the second half and you have higher revenues, why does the margin be somewhat less than what it was this quarter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, I'll take that. The revenues for the quarter were right around $40 million, I believe, is the number for preowned. And as is typical, it's right around breakeven, maybe $1 million or $2 million loss associated with those, which is pretty typica
componenttext: So George, I'll take that. The revenues for the quarter were right around $40 million, I believe, is the number for preowned. And as is typical, it's right around breakeven, maybe $1 million or $2 million loss associated with those, which is pretty typical. If I understand your question, for the balance of the year, we do have profiled, as we've talked about before, an expectation of additional preowned coming into inventory and being sold, which actually is consistent with the point Phebe made before with a little bit of a downtick in margins, particularly in the third quarter. So I think those are consistent, unless I misunderstood your question about the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's right, Jason. I just thought that to deliver 4 used planes in subsequent quarters, you're probably not going do that much, maybe you will. So I was kind of figuring the used planes would be less, so you got a little less pressure on the p
componenttext: No. I think it's right, Jason. I just thought that to deliver 4 used planes in subsequent quarters, you're probably not going do that much, maybe you will. So I was kind of figuring the used planes would be less, so you got a little less pressure on the profits and you got higher revenues. You've got higher revenue.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little bit more color on that. The planes in the quarter, there were 4 of them, but the mix of them, they were pretty modest in terms of revenue per unit. So that's not the assumption necessarily going forward. There are a lot of different mix in there
componenttext: A little bit more color on that. The planes in the quarter, there were 4 of them, but the mix of them, they were pretty modest in terms of revenue per unit. So that's not the assumption necessarily going forward. There are a lot of different mix in there in terms of inventory that we take in.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so think about it this way, George, we sold 4 in the quarter, which you know. We took in 3 and have sold 1. So today, we have 2 in inventory. But remember that the margin impact from -- can vary depending on the aircraft itself.
componenttext: Yes, so think about it this way, George, we sold 4 in the quarter, which you know. We took in 3 and have sold 1. So today, we have 2 in inventory. But remember that the margin impact from -- can vary depending on the aircraft itself.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a good answer. And one quick one. Combat margin is usually the biggest in the fourth quarter and yet your guidance is implying the second half won't be as good as the first half. So if you had a little explanation on that?
componenttext: Okay. That's a good answer. And one quick one. Combat margin is usually the biggest in the fourth quarter and yet your guidance is implying the second half won't be as good as the first half. So if you had a little explanation on that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are in the third and, more importantly, in the fourth quarter beginning to move from our -- as the domestic land forces contract, some of those begin to taper down, we are increasing our international production. So we have -- we've got -- that
componenttext: Yes. So we are in the third and, more importantly, in the fourth quarter beginning to move from our -- as the domestic land forces contract, some of those begin to taper down, we are increasing our international production. So we have -- we've got -- that's really the margin pressure, it's simply a question of mix. As long as operating performance is good, these guys have done very well, but they've got to come down their learning curves, right?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Hunter Keay of Wolfe Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: So if I understand your question properly, we had -- our sales on the 280 were a little different or a little better than we had anticipated. And I think that's just reflecting the strength of the North American market. So with respect to wait times, and let me give you this opportunity or take this opportunity to give you a little bit of color on the wait times. On the G650 and 50ER, we're about 24 months; 550 and 450, 9 to 12, no change; 280, 9 to 12; and the 150, we've got onesies and twosies left to sell there. So the first available there is a year from now.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the 280, better-than-expected that wasn't just timing, that was actually just maybe you just won a few more awards that could have gone either way?
componenttext: Okay. So on the 280, better-than-expected that wasn't just timing, that was actually just maybe you just won a few more awards that could have gone either way?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that that's right. That's always the case, right? We understand our customers needs, but the order in which they want to execute replacement of their fleet will kind of depend on their imminent needs for their -- imminent needs for the mis
componenttext: Yes. I think that that's right. That's always the case, right? We understand our customers needs, but the order in which they want to execute replacement of their fleet will kind of depend on their imminent needs for their -- imminent needs for the mission that a particular airplane serves. So the good news is, they're selling well, the 280s, but it does impact the bill.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski of Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski of Drexel Hamilton.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I guess, I'll ask you one on the Navy service program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial[ph] recapitalization. And I know you have some pote
componenttext: Phebe, I guess, I'll ask you one on the Navy service program. I'm wondering how you think about -- there seems to be some emerging chatter from the Democrats about the affordability of your nuclear trial[ph] recapitalization. And I know you have some potential CapEx, bills to pay, as you think about what would the right rates are going to be. So how you decide on your CapEx profile there at Marine, given kind of the sizable bills that Navy is going to have to pay and if they can pay those bills are not?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's often chatter when we -- and its been true from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a
componenttext: Well, there's often chatter when we -- and its been true from the last time that we recapitalized our nuclear fleet about the affordability of it. But this is really a national policy issue. And to the extent that the United States wants to maintain a nuclear deterrent, they've got to build this submarine. So that's #1, that's my view. And I think that that's supported by many people in the government on both the executive and the congressional side. So I wouldn't say that, that Democratic some chatter in the system suggests they're walking away from this requirement. So I think in terms of the -- the Navy has budgeted here a revenue flow to us that we can easily accommodate the CapEx and the other improvements that we have going forward in terms of the ability to build these. I might also tell you that we've been spending CapEx over the last few years to position ourselves, particularly at the quantum point on the Ohio replacement. So we work very carefully with our Navy customer to determine what they need, what we need, the funding allocation, who's responsible for what and we're certainly not going to get caught long.

componenttext: Do you think alternatively you keep the Virginia rate at 2 per year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q3 2016 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Erin Linnihan, Staff Vice Pre
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q3 2016 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Erin Linnihan, Staff Vice President of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chelsea, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter Conference Call. [ph] As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject t
componenttext:
Thank you, Chelsea, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter Conference Call. [ph] As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to [ph] turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin, and good morning all. As is apparent from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.40 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.73 billion, an income from continuing operations of
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin, and good morning all. As is apparent from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.40 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.73 billion, an income from continuing operations of $767 million. This is $0.20 per share better than the year-ago quarter and $0.10 per share better than consensus. Against the year-ago quarter, revenue is down $263 million or 3.3%. Operating earnings are up $35 million, a 3.4% increase. And income from continuing operations is up $34 million, a 4.6% increase.
This quarter's operating earnings of $1.07 billion reflect a 13.8% operating margin, 90 basis points better than the third quarter 2015. By the way, this is the eighth consecutive quarter [ph] that we have had those operating earnings and EBIT in excess of $1 billion.
Sequentially, revenue was [ph] up $66 million, almost 1%. Operating earnings are [ph] essentially flat, [ph] and operating margin is down 20 basis points.
On a year-to-date basis, revenue was off [ph] $540 million at 2.3% decrease. However, operating margins are up 50 basis points, [ph] and earnings from continuing operations are up $54 million, a 2.5% increase, once again reflecting our emphasis on continuous improvement in operations. [ph] Earnings per share from continuing operations are up $0.57 or 8.5% over last year.
I should point out that the entirety of the year-to-date revenue decrease is attributable to aerospace as we forecasted in January. The defense businesses have actually shown some modest growth year-to-date.
With respect to cash, we had [ph] $389 million of free cash flow from operations in the quarter. That is 51% of net income from continuing operations. We have $1.1 billion year-to-date, 50% in net income from continuing operations.
In the quarter, we repurchased 2.3 million shares for $348 million, offset in part by the exercise of $1.5 million option. We have purchased approximately 11.2 million shares year-to-date for about $1.5 billion. This is consistent with our prior guidance that we would repurchase shares and pay dividends [ph] in amounts in [ph] somewhat in [ph] excess of this year's free cash flow, much as we did last year.
As a reminder, in 2015, we had free cash flow of $1.9 billion and $4.1 billion on share repurchases and dividends. This year, we expect $2.2 billion on share repurchases [ph] and dividends year-to-date compared to a [ph] free cash flow of [ph] $1.1 billion, a delta of $1.1 billion. We will continue to use our balance sheet prudently and appropriately for the rest of the year. In short, we are honoring our word in these 2 years of low cash flow and using our balance sheet to offset lower cash.
As you can see from the chart attached to our press release, our very healthy backlog is holding nicely. Once again, there was good contract activity in all segments with particularly strong order intake at Gulfstream. We ended the quarter with a total backlog for the company of $62 billion, down modestly from the end of last quarter. Of that amount, $51.4 billion is funded.
Let me say a few words about each of our groups. Let me start with Aerospace. Aerospace had another very good quarter. Revenue was down $326 million or 13.9% compared to the third quarter 2015, in line with the production cuts to the 450, [ph] 550 [ph] and, to a lesser extent, the 280 [ph] that we have previously discussed with you. Also remember that Q3 2015 was the group's highest ever revenue quarter.
On the other hand, operating earnings increased $11 million or 2.6% to $437 million on an operating margin of 21.7%, a 350 basis point improvement over the year-ago quarter. This is a real tribute to the operating efficiency of the Gulfstream and Jet Aviation teams. By the way, this is the ninth consecutive quarter with operating earnings in excess of $400 million and the highest ever margin for the group.
On a sequential basis, the group experienced $117 million reduction in revenue, 5.5%, but [ph] a $3 million improvement in operating earnings on 140 basis point improvement in margin. On a year-to-date basis, revenue was down $571 million or 8.5%. [ph] Operating earnings are down $14 million or 1.1% on 160 basis point improvement in [ph] operating margin.
On this last quarter -- on the call last quarter, we advised that we were quite optimistic regarding order activity in the third quarter. Our optimism was well founded. We had [ph] strong order intake in the quarter for the group, a 0.9:1 book-to-bill measuring in dollar value of [ph] orders. [ph] Gulfstream alone was about 1:1 on a dollar-value basis and 1.2:1 on a [ph] number of units [ph] basis. The distribution of these orders is also attractive, [ph] with the G650 and 650ER leading the way. I can also tell you that our pipeline of prospects grew, [ph] and our active sales discussions are quite good. We are again reasonably optimistic about order intake in the fourth quarter and expect it to look [ph] much like the third quarter. By the way, this was the strongest discreet [ph] third quarter since 2011 for orders.
Next, Combat Systems. Combat had a very good quarter with revenue of $1.33 billion, operating earnings of $219 million and a really strong 16.5% operating margin. Compared to the third quarter of 2015, revenue was off [ph] $15 million, [ph] but earnings are up $1 million on a 30 basis point improvement in margin. On a sequential basis, revenue was up $15 million, [ph] and operating earnings are [ph] flat. Year-to-date, revenue is down against 2015 by $198 million or 4.8%. Operating earnings are up $7 million or 1.1% on 100 basis point improvement in operating margin.
Combat Systems [ph] remains on course for a very good year, [ph] and we fully anticipate that their fourth quarter earnings will see a 30% increase in revenue. All of our major programs are performing very well in Combat. Our cost performance has improved our competitiveness, which positions us well for the future. We continue [ph] -- and for the rest of the [ph] year, by the way. We continue to see opportunities for growth, both internationally, as allied nations continue to see increased emerging threats; and domestically, as the U.S. Army and Marine Corps begin to recapitalize their equipment.
The Marine group reported revenue of $2.04 billion, a $44 million or 2.1% decrease compared to the year-ago quarter. [ph] However, revenue was up sequentially by $56 million or 2.8%. Year-to-date, revenue has [ph] increased by $130 million or 2.2% to $6.2 billion. Operating earnings for the third quarter at $166 million is down by $15 million compared to last year's quarter. The group's operating margins were down 60 basis [ph] in the quarter as a result of a onetime [ph] charge at FAS [ph] on their restart of the DDG 115 and 116 program. This charge flows through to the sequential and year-to-date comparisons as well.
IS&T. [ph] Well, IS&T continues to outperform somewhat our revenue expectation. Revenue of $2.34 billion is up $122 million or 5.5% against last year's quarter and up $112 million sequentially, also a 5% increase. Year-to-date revenue of $6.9 billion is up $99 million or 1.5% over last year. Operating earnings of $256 million are up $37 million or 16.9% compared to the third quarter last year on the strength of 100 basis point improvement in operating margin. Sequentially, the story is much the same. Operating earnings are up $12 million on a 10.9% operating margin in both quarters. [ph] Year-to-date, operating earnings are up $75 million, an [ph] 11.1% increase on a 90 basis point improvement in operating margin.
This is a very good news story, with both revenue and operating margins higher than expected. Really strong performance by IS&T.
So what does all this mean as far as the year is [ph] concerned? [ph] Well, stronger-than-expected [ph] operating results in the quarter, a lower-than-planned [ph] tax rate and modestly lower share count enable [ph] us to increase guidance for the year by $0.05. Our guidance for [ph] EPS from continuing operations [ph] goes from $9.70 to $9.75. This way [ph] in the year, we anticipate our ended year guidance to be pretty close to actual performance.
And finally, in closing, as tempting as it is this time of year for some of you to ask about the following year, let me just remind you that we have a planning process in the fall when the businesses get better insight into the upcoming year. That guidance, which is we give [ph] to you in January, is grounded in that process, [ph] and as a result, it's full and thorough. So I don't want to prematurely tease [ph] you at this juncture.
I would now like to turn the call over to our CFO, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a few things to cover before we start the Q&A period. First, some background on the charge in discontinued operations.Back in 2013, we settled the 1991 litigation with the U.S. Navy rela
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a few things to cover before we start the Q&A period. First, some background on the charge in discontinued operations.
Back in 2013, we settled the 1991 litigation with the U.S. Navy related to the terminated A-12 aircraft contract in [ph] our former tactical military aircraft business, retiring in excess of $1 billion in [ph] potential risk to the company. In connection with that settlement, we provided various forms of consideration to the Navy, including the release of some rights for [ph] the potential reimbursement of costs that affected all ships under contract at the time at our main shipyard. As we progressed through the shipbuilding process, we [ph] determined that the costs [ph] associated with the settlement is greater than the party has [ph] anticipated. Therefore, we recognized [ph] an $84 million loss, [ph] net of taxes, to adjust the previously recognized settlement value.
As we discussed throughout this year, we're seeing an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility. It's still not material in the aggregate, but it continues to be a slight top line drag on some of our segments, particularly Combat Systems. As Phebe pointed out, the group's revenue declined by [ph] 1.1% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. But had foreign exchange rates, particularly the U.S. dollar to the euro [ph] and the Canadian dollar, held constant from 2015, the group sales would have remained steady quarter-over-quarter.
Moving on to interest expense. The net expense in the quarter was $23 million, similar to the third quarter of 2015. For the full year, we expect net interest expense to be approximately $95 million. In July, we repaid $500 million of maturing debt with cash on hand and subsequently issued $1 billion of new debt in the quarter. Despite the net increase in long-term notes, our net debt [ph] position remains unchanged from the end of the [ph] second quarter at approximately $1.6 billion.
We finished the quarter with a cash balance of $2.3 billion after deploying over $550 million in share repurchases and dividends in the quarter. We funded our pension plans as expected in the quarter and continue to expect cash pension contributions for 2016 to approximate $200 million. Our effective tax rate was 26.8% for the quarter, somewhat lower than we expected as a result of tax benefits from employee stock option exercises and other true-ups associated with the filing of our tax return. For the full year, we expect an effective tax rate in the high 28% range.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn it back over [ph] to you for the Q&A.

componenttext: So Phebe, just a quick question. componenttext: Well, [ph] so much for not getting into 2017. Look, we have as a goal double-digit growth, but it's too soon for me to tell how 2017 plays out. So if you want to [ph] ask another question, go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Okay. So let's -- maybe just to follow up on -- [ph] in the quarter, you mentioned that sales of [ph] Gulfstream were good, right? [ph] And then [ph] we have book-to-bill of 1 or over 1, depending on how you want to measure it. Would -- can you give
componenttext: Sure. Okay. So let's -- maybe just to follow up on -- [ph] in the quarter, you mentioned that sales of [ph] Gulfstream were good, right? [ph] And then [ph] we have book-to-bill of 1 or over 1, depending on how you want to measure it. Would -- can you give me [ph] maybe a little more color on kind of regional distribution and what -- how 650 was doing because, as you know, there's been worry about sales of 650s, that kind of thing?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, you asked about [ph] the regional distribution, [ph] and I think if we're stepping back a moment and talking in the general and then in the [ph] specific. [ph] And let's start by talking about the market. And let me try to give you some insi
componenttext: Yes. So look, you asked about [ph] the regional distribution, [ph] and I think if we're stepping back a moment and talking in the general and then in the [ph] specific. [ph] And let's start by talking about the market. And let me try to give you some insight into our market. Let's start with, for example, the Honeywell study, which measures deliveries, [ph] not orders. Deliveries in the business jet market are down, [ph] including somewhat at [ph] Gulfstream, right? For the good and valid reasons that we have discussed during our transition -- [ph] discussed with you previously during our transition from the 450 and 550 to 650 -- or 550 and 600 or 500 and 600. Deliveries, however, are based on retrospective orders, so 12 to 24 months previously. And for Gulfstream, from an order perspective, we have seen and continue to see nice demand. So it would appear that we had [ph] been taking share from other than our space. And as the 500 and 600 enter into service, we really anticipate that we will continue to take share. I've been reluctant to -- in the past year or so to get into a share discussion because we really are about -- not about share, but really about profit. But it would appear that we are indeed taking share. So I think that understanding where we are positioned today and how we're [ph] positioned going forward will help you. It would also appear, specifically to your question, that we are far less dependent on the BRIC countries and on, frankly, [ph] any one particular region outside North America. And our demand consequently has not been as [ph] stated as other [ph] seems to be. So to give you a sense of, I think, where do we stand in the market and how we see it in general. Now let's dig down a little bit deeper in the Gulfstream, [ph] and let's just think about this. So from a Gulfstream perspective, again, as measured by our sales pipeline and order activity with respect to demand, both are stable and sufficient to get us through to the new aircraft. I mentioned that the third quarter orders are the strongest in 5 years, [ph] and interestingly, both our fourth quarter activity to date and [ph] the pipeline are good. If we think about Gulfstream more specifically, let me talk to you and just give you [ph] a little bit of color without getting into guidance. This is just color in the most broad sense. The G500 will most certainly make a contribution in 2017 and a significant one in 2018. The amount of the 2017 contribution, of course, will be dependent on the timing of the [ph] certification. The 600 should make a contribution in 2018 and a significant contribution in '19. So why am I confident in talking to you all about this? I'll tell you why. It's because the test program for both airplanes are going very well. The G500 is doing well in tests, [ph] and it should be certified and entered into service in 2017 [ph] as we have just talked about. The 600 will fly this quarter and should be certified and enter into service and all on schedule with some forward bias. Thinking about, again, this broadly, our market in Gulfstream, [ph] in particular, has [ph] always been of the view that a new plane [ph] 50 solid orders before the commencement of initial production have a good start. Well, the 500 kind of exceed that number, which is quite good, especially when you consider those sales force has been incentivized to focus on the 450 and 550. They're [ph] now being [ph] incentivized to turn their attention toward the 500. So with respect to used airplanes, some of you have been very concerned about that. Let me talk to you a [ph] little bit about where we are in the used market. We see in the 650 market, I think there are about 19 to 20 airplanes that are up for sale, [ph] but as we deconstruct and analyze those [ph] potential aircraft, we see maybe 12 to 14 serious sellers, dedicated sellers. So that's well within the 10% of the 200 and some -- 203, actually, 650s that we've got into service. And we haven't seen any impact this [ph] quarter on new order activity or our [ph] order activity from the used market. And with respect to the 550, the used market is about 7% of the 700-or-so [ph] aircraft in service. And so we haven't been affected by that either. So I know that, that [ph] was rather soliloquy, but I think it's been [ph] -- your question about the distribution of [ph] our market, I think, was [ph] particularly -- just give me an opportunity to talk to you guys a little bit more [ph] about the market, but I hope that helped.[ph]

componenttext: Well, you're quite right that [ph] instead of [ph] we're going to try -- we intended to keep earnings as flat as we could [ph] and margins as high as we could during this transition period [ph], just to be at bit [ph] cyclical. componenttext: Can you explain to me -- I mean, for the deliveries that you made, we're [ph] pretty much in line with where we were guessing. We had less profit by $30-plus million. So was it lower R&D? [ph] Was it supplier payments? [ph] Was it forfeitures? [ph] Was it better margins? What got you to [ph] a number that strong? headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've talked before, aerospace margins and Gulfstream, [ph] in particular, are variable quarter-over-quarter. [ph] But what you're seeing here is a result of the Gulfstream team doing [ph] a superb job taking costs out [ph] as the revenue has declin
componenttext: Well, we've talked before, aerospace margins and Gulfstream, [ph] in particular, are variable quarter-over-quarter. [ph] But what you're seeing here is a result of the Gulfstream team doing [ph] a superb job taking costs out [ph] as the revenue has declined, [ph] and they've done a very good job with that in the quarter. R&D was somewhat lower. We had some timing issues [ph] at Jet Aviation. We don't anticipate that performance going forward in margins, but they will continue to do quite well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on how you think about the transition to the 500, 600 from a margin or a cost standpoint, I guess. [ph] Clearly, it's come out [ph] you'll end the [ph] 450 production in '18, [ph] and you [ph] just made the [ph] comment about the contribu
componenttext: Just a quick one on how you think about the transition to the 500, 600 from a margin or a cost standpoint, I guess. [ph] Clearly, it's come out [ph] you'll end the [ph] 450 production in '18, [ph] and you [ph] just made the [ph] comment about the contribution you expect from the 500 and 600 and how that layers in, [ph] in '17 and '18. But with those aircraft being produced in different facilities, how should we think about the ramp-down [ph] on the 450 and then, eventually, [ph] the 550 [ph] and how that impacts the overall cost structure of the segment?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We've talked last year or so about the [ph] -- how we're going to manage the transition as we wind down the 450 and 550 and then bring on the 500 and 600. And the key there is matching the ship set, the wings, the fuselage, the engines, with the num
componenttext: Okay. We've talked last year or so about the [ph] -- how we're going to manage the transition as we wind down the 450 and 550 and then bring on the 500 and 600. And the key there is matching the ship set, the wings, the fuselage, the engines, with the number of airplanes that we have left to sell or left to deliver. And so far, with the 150, [ph] for example, we got it spot on. We're on track to get that perfect correlation on the 450, [ph] and I expect the same thing on the 550. So I don't anticipate any decrease in margins as a result of our failure to make that transition really comfortable and profitable. That said, as we -- look, [ph] think about it, any time you have a mix shift, which is what Gulfstream is going to have, right, [ph] you're going to have a mix shift as we go from older production, long-running lines, long historic earning curves as we enter and start to produce and deliver 500 and 600. But I will tell you, if you look at the 650 by comparison, unless you see that [ph] as our baseline, the 650 margin performance was faster and higher than the 550 before it. So we've taken [ph] -- that means it's [ph] coming down this learning curve, [ph] and we're seeing gross margin expansion earlier than we had ever [ph] before. So the lessons that we have learned on the 650, we are translating into how we go about the production on the 500 and 600. And that gives me an awful lot of confidence that this team is going to hit the ground running. We may have some margin compression as we begin to deliver. We come down those learning curves, but those -- our ability to come down those learning curves, as we demonstrated, I believe, is [ph] going to go much, much faster. And remember, too, there's a fair amount of commonality between the 500 and 600. So I suspect that the ignition coming down -- when we bring that 650 into full -- or 600 into full-rate [ph] production, it's going to be pretty impressive. I got to tell you, I like where we are, I like where we're headed. [ph] We're moving through this transition period [ph] like I told you we were going to do. And we're in good shape for real revenue and earnings growth as we get these 2 new airplanes into service.

componenttextpreview: Sure. So the fourth quarter revenue increase is driven primarily by a couple of things, [ph] the Canadian, Middle East [ph] order and our AJAX programs, as they move from engineering and low-rate [ph] production in the third quarter and the full-rate prod
componenttext: Sure. So the fourth quarter revenue increase is driven primarily by a couple of things, [ph] the Canadian, Middle East [ph] order and our AJAX programs, as they move from engineering and low-rate [ph] production in the third quarter and the full-rate production in the fourth quarter. So you're going to see some real -- and by the way, we got this -- Combat has this analyzed and down to a fine level of detail. And that's -- we have those -- that growth in our backlog, [ph] and we are positioned on both of those programs. So those are [ph] going to drive it primarily. But we pull [ph] also, Combat tends to have very robust revenue growth in the fourth quarter, and we'll -- [ph] across the [ph] portfolio, [ph] and we'll continue to see that in OTS and ELS [ph] as well as Land Systems. So it -- there isn't much ambiguity this way [ph] in the year with a group that really understands their products and how they're going to [ph] begin to execute.

componenttext: Phebe, I'm curious about that comment you made about the sales force having their incentive changed around the new programs flipping to the 500 and 600 from the 450, 550. headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, they're not going to give in to how we -- if I can give you sense, just in general, it's the case here is that sales force is incentivized to sell whatever product we, at the moment, are focused on. And so their bonuses are significant part of
componenttext: Well, look, they're not going to give in to how we -- if I can give you sense, just in general, it's the case here is that sales force is incentivized to sell whatever product we, at the moment, are focused on. And so their bonuses are significant part of their compensation and it's up to us to give them the direction of where we're going to have them focus. So this has been a very effective sales support as I think you can see from our order activity.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the think about it, the 450, we've announced -- that line is going to end, surprisingly, right? The replacement aircraft by definition are going to replace airplanes that we're winding down. And so -- and the 550 has continued to have very nice orde
componenttext: Well, the think about it, the 450, we've announced -- that line is going to end, surprisingly, right? The replacement aircraft by definition are going to replace airplanes that we're winding down. And so -- and the 550 has continued to have very nice order activity. So we're pretty confident that it's time now to move more robustly to the 500. And let me tell you, even incentivized as they were, as I mentioned in my remarks, they have -- we have sold quite a few. So we're in pretty good shape here.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm so inclined to ask a Gulfstream question but you've -- I won't do that. Instead, talk a little bit about Information Systems and Technology. I mean, you've stated that there's been a change and it's sort of taking on the growth profile. Can you elabor
componenttext: I'm so inclined to ask a Gulfstream question but you've -- I won't do that. Instead, talk a little bit about Information Systems and Technology. I mean, you've stated that there's been a change and it's sort of taking on the growth profile. Can you elaborate a little bit upon what some of the pillars are that are behind us? And what -- how you'd like to shape it going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me kind of take that in 2 parts. And let's start with our book-to-bill, because I think that's reflects a lot of the promoting parts. In the quarter, we had a book-to-bill about 0.8:1 and this sort for this short cycled business. And think about it in
componenttext: Let me kind of take that in 2 parts. And let's start with our book-to-bill, because I think that's reflects a lot of the promoting parts. In the quarter, we had a book-to-bill about 0.8:1 and this sort for this short cycled business. And think about it in terms of the last 8 quarters or last 8 of the last 11 quarters for this group, have had a 1:1 or greater book-to-bill, which is really quite exceptional in the short term, in short, these highly transactional businesses. So that gives us the platform for some of this ignition and in terms of where we're focused on our platform side, we've got a number of growth opportunities cross platform portfolio. Our business and space payload market, cyber, payload market, cyber, nuclear weapons and avionics. So I like where they are there. And on our IT side, we have had nice book-to-bills and we've got a number of wins that we've had across the entirety of the portfolio. And I'll tell you, not that you remember we also have incentives in there which will be a nice cost plus award fee program for 5 years and we like how that fits into our low-risk cash generating portfolio. And then going forward, we've got an awful lot of competitions coming up and we tend to announce those as we win them or we put them into our backlog. So the diving board for that sort of -- for our growth is there in our backlog and because these businesses have really reduced their costs and increase their competitiveness, their book-to-bill has been wholesome for quite some time now and I expect it to be going forward.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then actually, as a follow-up, if you do the flight hours on the G500, you're clearly ahead of schedule. Can you provide us a little bit of an indication of when you think in the first half of '17 you might get the cert?
componenttext: And then actually, as a follow-up, if you do the flight hours on the G500, you're clearly ahead of schedule. Can you provide us a little bit of an indication of when you think in the first half of '17 you might get the cert?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think first half is actually ambitious, but I'll be able to give you in January a lot more clarity when we get the full certification timeline from the FAA, but I'm very confident we're going to start in '17.
componenttext: I think first half is actually ambitious, but I'll be able to give you in January a lot more clarity when we get the full certification timeline from the FAA, but I'm very confident we're going to start in '17.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: So when you look at it, can you talk about the general trajectory of revenues and earnings over the next 5 years as you move toward the first ship? And also, what investments might be needed to really set Electric Boat up for the scale of operations that will ultimately be there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Let me give you a little bit, because this is such a big program, let me give you a little bit of detail on what's going on on the Ohio replacement. We have been in the -- we have had the designed contract now for about 5 years and we're procee
componenttext: All right. Let me give you a little bit, because this is such a big program, let me give you a little bit of detail on what's going on on the Ohio replacement. We have been in the -- we have had the designed contract now for about 5 years and we're proceeding nicely at pace. And as you know, we had a prime contractor for the design for the sole contractor and the prime contractor for the construction. So our schedule is right on point to start the construction of the lead ship in 2021. And I would imagine that -- well, I expect that our profile on revenue within -- between now and 2021 where we'll really begin the real ignition will be driven by a couple of things, 1, we'll continue to have further design work on the Ohio and -- which will begin to ramp down as we get closer and closer, but starting perhaps '19, I think we're anticipating '19, we're likely to see a long lead production so we can actually -- we can actualize the ship productions construction in 2021. So as you know, these submarine programs take -- require a fair amount of long lead material in order to ensure that you stay on your construction schedule. So to give you a sense of where we are in the design and the component development, well, we've proposed a detailed design and actually all the component development design to the Navy earlier this summer. And they'd like to give us an award by the end of the year. And you know what, when you think about the large national strategic program, one of the most important things that we all get right is that the cost is well understood. So one of the things that we've been driving our work over the last 3 years is the bottom of analysis that the full process of construction. So that will be an important element as we work through those costs with the Navy. And once we get some clarity about the schedule and the pace, then we'll be able to have more clarity about specifics on that production ramp because it will all be very public and obvious.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at Electric Boat though, this is -- this will really change what the operations look like out there. I mean, how do you think about planning for that?
componenttext: When you look at Electric Boat though, this is -- this will really change what the operations look like out there. I mean, how do you think about planning for that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look. I'm sorry, you did offset my fall. We have begun making the investment over the last 5 years. The investments are primarily funded by the Navy, but we will also and have been putting some of our capital and we will continue to because what we
componenttext: Well, look. I'm sorry, you did offset my fall. We have begun making the investment over the last 5 years. The investments are primarily funded by the Navy, but we will also and have been putting some of our capital and we will continue to because what we invest in lines of business that have higher returns for us and good returns for us and this is one of those lines of business. And it is transformative. You put Ohio on top of Virginia and there's going to be quite a lot of workload, but we have spent the last 5 years with getting our facilities in place, our design tools are mature, the design to build tools are also very mature and we need to work -- we need to get our workforce because we're going to have this increase in volume, we're going to be bringing in a fair number of great labor. We had a robust education program in the trade with Rhode Island and Connecticut. And that will provide us the foundation to really be able to start full rate production on schedule on the Ohio replacement and continue on Virginia class. Shipbuilding, one of the competitive advantages for shipbuilding is that detailed planning is physical and that's something that Electric Boat has excelled at for a decade and has demonstrated, yet again, in their preparation for the Ohio. So we have detailed hiring plans, training plans, CapEx plans with the Navy. And of course, our design work that we also have a lots of the Navy on. So these are all about preparing for success. And so far, so good.

componenttext: So I think we've used a couple different terms in the past. We've talked about normalizing versus the lower free cash flow in these couple of years. But I think the key point is we've had a tremendous amount of cash in the balance sheet coming in at the past couple of years. A lot of that was timing for a number of things that we've talked about over the past several quarters. And at this point, the key is we're committed to using the balance sheet to again sort of normalizing that free cash flow at a lower level to return that capital.

componenttext: And look, think about it this way, we've long been talking about this 2 years of fairly low cash flow. I think about it more like where are we in cash flow, where are we on the balance sheet and what are -- what resources do we have to continue to go buy shares and other investments as needed and I think we've managed it pretty prudently. But I think about it as where our cash flow is and where our cash deployment -- where our cash flow is and what our balance sheet looks like. We've been pretty consistent.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Well, let's talk about the Middle East for a moment in general. And this particular customer, we have had a 50-year productive relationship with the kingdom and the vast preponderance of all of our combat programs are government-to-government and the contracts have been and products have been fully vetted and supported and this all happen to be products that the customer want and need. So we have seen no indication from the end-user customer that there is concern on their part or an intent on their part to change the profile of these -- of our deliveries and look, we will -- we got these large advances and we've been working those down and we'll continue to refresh cash flow as we, from these customers, as we increase deliveries. And so far, we're in pretty good shape.

componenttext: Okay. If I could just ask one more, Phebe, maybe for Jason, but follow-up to Doug's question. headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. And then looking out to 2018, you suggested that the 500 will contribute in that year and then meaningfully -- excuse me, in '17 and meaningfully in 2018. You've also suggested in the past that you've got some delivery response that are avai
componenttext: Yes, it does. And then looking out to 2018, you suggested that the 500 will contribute in that year and then meaningfully -- excuse me, in '17 and meaningfully in 2018. You've also suggested in the past that you've got some delivery response that are available on the 650 out there in the second quarter of 2018. I was wondering if you could update us on that. And what I'm trying to figure out here is whether if you're going to have enough orders on the 650 to hold production flat out there in 2018 or if the plan here is to begin taking production rates down on that and having any hold from an EBIT perspective that gets created by the 650 decline and filled in by the 500. And that's kind of the key to the recipe of holding EBIT flat through these transitions.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, what we've said all along is that, to use that wonderful word  we'll start an additional 650s, but that production rate during the transition is not sustainable nor healthy and that we would never intend to keep that production laid up. What
componenttext: Yes. So look, what we've said all along is that, to use that wonderful word  we'll start an additional 650s, but that production rate during the transition is not sustainable nor healthy and that we would never intend to keep that production laid up. What we aim for is to keep our backlog on 650s any of our programs, particularly that one, between 18 months and 2 years and we're now 2 years again. So as we think about that, I mean, that order book is there for -- we've got now 2 years next available. So that ought to give you a little bit of color on how we intend to think through as we set our deliveries and our delivery schedule. But I have not set and we haven't set until later in -- late November or mid-November, production schedule for next year. So on the fourth quarter call, I'll give you copious details what we plan on doing. Okay?
