headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I'm curious about that comment you made about the sales force having their incentive changed around the new programs flipping to the 500 and 600 from the 450, 550. Can you help me understand a little bit how -- first of all, when that happened, and
componenttext: Phebe, I'm curious about that comment you made about the sales force having their incentive changed around the new programs flipping to the 500 and 600 from the 450, 550. Can you help me understand a little bit how -- first of all, when that happened, and how material of a change is this in their own lives? Is this like a significant driver of their compensation structure? Or is it like a small thing in their bonus? I'm just kind of trying to think about...

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I'm not going to get in to how we -- but to give you a sense, just in general, the theory of the case here is that sales force is incentivized to sell whatever product we, at the moment, are focused on. And so their bonuses are a significant p
componenttext: Well, look, I'm not going to get in to how we -- but to give you a sense, just in general, the theory of the case here is that sales force is incentivized to sell whatever product we, at the moment, are focused on. And so their bonuses are a significant part of their compensation, and it's up to us to give them the direction of where we're going to have them focused. So this has been a very effective sales force, as I think you can see from our order activity.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Did this just change within the last few months? Or is this -- has it been in there for 6, 9 months, something like that? Or is it just like something that has changed effective at the end of the year?
componenttext: Sure. Did this just change within the last few months? Or is this -- has it been in there for 6, 9 months, something like that? Or is it just like something that has changed effective at the end of the year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, think about it, the 450 we've announced is we're going to -- that line is going to end, not surprisingly, right? The replacement aircraft by definition are going to replace airplanes that are -- that we're winding down. And so -- and the 550 h
componenttext: Well, look, think about it, the 450 we've announced is we're going to -- that line is going to end, not surprisingly, right? The replacement aircraft by definition are going to replace airplanes that are -- that we're winding down. And so -- and the 550 has continued to have very nice order activity. So we're pretty confident that it's time now to move more robustly to the 500. And let me tell you, even incentivized as they were, as I mentioned in my remarks, they have -- we have sold quite a few. So we're in pretty good shape here.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm so inclined to ask a Gulfstream question, but you've answered all...
componenttext: I'm so inclined to ask a Gulfstream question, but you've answered all...

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead.
componenttext: Go ahead.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, I won't do that. Instead, talk a little bit about Information Systems and Technology. I mean, you've stated that there's been a change, and it's sort of taking on a growth profile. Can you elaborate a little bit upon what some of the pillars are t
componenttext: No, no, I won't do that. Instead, talk a little bit about Information Systems and Technology. I mean, you've stated that there's been a change, and it's sort of taking on a growth profile. Can you elaborate a little bit upon what some of the pillars are that are behind this and what -- how you'd like to shape it going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Let me kind of take that in 2 parts. And let's start with our book-to-bill, because I think that, that reflects a lot of different moving parts. In the quarter, we had a book-to-bill about 0.8:1, and that's solid for this short-cycle business.
componenttext: All right. Let me kind of take that in 2 parts. And let's start with our book-to-bill, because I think that, that reflects a lot of different moving parts. In the quarter, we had a book-to-bill about 0.8:1, and that's solid for this short-cycle business. And think about it in terms of the last 8 quarters -- or last -- 8 of the last 11 quarters for this group have had a 1:1 or greater book-to-bill, which is really quite exceptional in the short term, and so short -- these highly transactional businesses. So that gives us the platform for some of this ignition. And in terms of where we're focused on our platform side, we've got a number of growth opportunities in -- across our platform portfolio, in our ISR business in space payload market, cyber -- payload market, cyber, nuclear weapons and avionics. So I like where they are there. On our IT side, we have had nice book-to-bills, and we've got a number of wins that we've had across the entirety of the portfolio. And I'll tell you, not that -- you remember we also had the Census in there, which will be a nice cost-plus award fee program for 5 years. And we like how that fits into our low-risk cash-generating portfolio. And then going forward, we've got an awful lot of competitions coming up, and we tend to announce those as we win them or we put them into our backlog. So the diving board for that sort of -- for our growth is there in our backlog. And because these businesses have really reduced their costs and increased their competitiveness, their book-to-bill has been wholesome for quite some time now, and I expect it to be going forward.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, actually, I do want to as a follow-up, if you do the flight hours on the G500, you're clearly ahead of schedule. Can you provide us a little bit of an indication of when you think in the first half of '17 you might get the cert?
componenttext: And then, actually, I do want to as a follow-up, if you do the flight hours on the G500, you're clearly ahead of schedule. Can you provide us a little bit of an indication of when you think in the first half of '17 you might get the cert?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think first half is a touch ambitious, but I'll be able to give you in January a lot more clarity when we get the full certification timeline from the FAA. But I'm very confident we're going to start in '17.
componenttext: I think first half is a touch ambitious, but I'll be able to give you in January a lot more clarity when we get the full certification timeline from the FAA. But I'm very confident we're going to start in '17.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned with Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned with Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask, on Marine, on the Ohio-class Replacement program, because the scale of that program is so large that one would expect it to transform Electric Boat in the next decade, and particularly, if we see Virginia class stay at 2 per year...
componenttext: I wanted to ask, on Marine, on the Ohio-class Replacement program, because the scale of that program is so large that one would expect it to transform Electric Boat in the next decade, and particularly, if we see Virginia class stay at 2 per year...

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's my view.
componenttext: That's my view.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when you look at it, can you talk about the general trajectory of revenues and earnings over the next 5 years as you move toward the first ship? And also, what investments might be needed to really set Electric Boat up for the scale of operations that
componenttext: So when you look at it, can you talk about the general trajectory of revenues and earnings over the next 5 years as you move toward the first ship? And also, what investments might be needed to really set Electric Boat up for the scale of operations that will ultimately be there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Let me give you a little bit -- because this is such a big program, let me give you a little bit of detail on what's going on, on the Ohio replacement. We have been in the -- we have had the design contract now for about 5 years, and we're proc
componenttext: All right. Let me give you a little bit -- because this is such a big program, let me give you a little bit of detail on what's going on, on the Ohio replacement. We have been in the -- we have had the design contract now for about 5 years, and we're proceeding nicely apace. As you know, we're the prime contractor for the design, the sole contractor and the prime contractor for the construction. So our schedule is right on point to start the construction of the lead ship in 2021. And I would imagine that -- well, I expect that our profile on revenue within -- between now and 2021, where we'll really begin to see the real ignition, will be driven by a couple of things. One, we'll continue to have further design work on the Ohio and -- which we'll begin to ramp down as we get closer and closer. But starting perhaps in '19, and I think we're anticipating '19, we're likely to see a long lead production so we can actually -- we can actualize the ship production construction in 2021. So as you know, these submarine programs take -- require a fair amount of long lead material in order to ensure that you stay on your construction schedule. So to give you a sense of where we are in the design and the component development, well, we have proposed a detailed design and actually all the component development design to the Navy earlier this summer, and they'd like to give us an award by the end of the year. And when you think about the large nationally strategic programs, one of the most important things that we all get right is that the costs are well understood. And so one of the things that we've been driving our work the last 3 years is a bottom up analysis of the full process of construction. So that will be an important element as we work through those costs with the Navy. And once we get some clarity about the schedule and the pace, then we'll be able to have more clarity about specifics on that production ramp because it will all be very public and obvious.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: But -- when you look at Electric Boat, though, this is -- this will really change what the operations look like up there. Is it -- I mean, how do you think about planning for that?
componenttext: But -- when you look at Electric Boat, though, this is -- this will really change what the operations look like up there. Is it -- I mean, how do you think about planning for that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I'm sorry, you did ask that, my fault. We have begun making the investments over the last 5 years. The investments have primarily been funded by the Navy, but we will also and have been putting some of our capital in, and we'll continue to bec
componenttext: Well, look, I'm sorry, you did ask that, my fault. We have begun making the investments over the last 5 years. The investments have primarily been funded by the Navy, but we will also and have been putting some of our capital in, and we'll continue to because -- look, we invest in lines of business that have high returns for us and good returns for us, and this is one of those lines of business. And it is transformative. You put Ohio on top of Virginia, and there's going to be quite a lot of workload. So we have spent the last 5 years with getting our facilities in place. Our design tools are mature. The design to build tools are also very mature, and we need to work -- we need to get our workforce because we're going to have this increase in volume. We're going to be bringing in a fair number of green labor. We have a robust education program in the trades with Rhode Island and Connecticut. And that will provide us the foundation to really be able to start full-rate production on schedule on the Ohio replacement and continue on Virginia class. Shipbuilding -- one of the competitive advantages in shipbuilding is that detailed planning is critical, and that's something that Electric Boat has excelled at for decades, and has demonstrated yet again in their preparation for the Ohio. So we have detailed hiring plans, training plans, CapEx plans with the Navy. And of course, our design work that we also are in lockstep with the Navy on. So this is all about preparing for success, and so far, so good.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one is a clarification, Phebe. I think you said that you're going to do repurchase and dividends slightly ahead of your free cash flow. I just wanted to clarify, and maybe I misunderstood. I thought previously it was 100% of net income and you kind
componenttext: First one is a clarification, Phebe. I think you said that you're going to do repurchase and dividends slightly ahead of your free cash flow. I just wanted to clarify, and maybe I misunderstood. I thought previously it was 100% of net income and you kind of make up the difference for repurchasing cash flow.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Myles, I think we've used a couple different terms in the past. We've talked about normalizing versus the lower free cash flow in these couple of years. But I think the key point is we had, had a tremendous amount of cash on the balance sheet coming in
componenttext: So Myles, I think we've used a couple different terms in the past. We've talked about normalizing versus the lower free cash flow in these couple of years. But I think the key point is we had, had a tremendous amount of cash on the balance sheet coming in at the past couple of years. A lot of that was timing for a number of the things that we've talked about over the past several quarters. And at this point, the key is we are committed to using that balance sheet to, again, sort of normalizing that free cash flow at a lower level to return that capital.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And look, think about it this way. We've long been talking about these 2 years of fairly low cash flow. We need to normalize that cash flow and then augment it by our balance sheet, and we've done that. I think about it more like where are we in cash flow
componenttext: And look, think about it this way. We've long been talking about these 2 years of fairly low cash flow. We need to normalize that cash flow and then augment it by our balance sheet, and we've done that. I think about it more like where are we in cash flow, where are we on the balance sheet and what are -- what resources do we have to continue to go buy shares and other investments as needed? And I think we've managed that pretty prudently. So I think about it as where our cash flow is and where our cash deployment -- where our cash flow is and what our balance sheet looks like. We've been pretty consistent.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the conversion for '16, do you think you can still get close to the '15 conversion level at 65%?
componenttext: Okay. And the conversion for '16, do you think you can still get close to the '15 conversion level at 65%?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll have to see on that, but we've got plenty of powder in our balance sheet. So there's been no material change from the guidance that we gave you back in January about our cash flow. Think about it that way.
componenttext: We'll have to see on that, but we've got plenty of powder in our balance sheet. So there's been no material change from the guidance that we gave you back in January about our cash flow. Think about it that way.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn with Crdit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the cash flow, you've had this drawdown on the advances in Combat Systems on the large contracts you talked about before, the Middle East lab and the AJAX, and you've got the growth in Q4. But does that trend continue next year? Is there any concern th
componenttext: On the cash flow, you've had this drawdown on the advances in Combat Systems on the large contracts you talked about before, the Middle East lab and the AJAX, and you've got the growth in Q4. But does that trend continue next year? Is there any concern that the Middle East customer might slow the intake of deliveries, especially as those cash advances get exhausted and just given what were the potentially scarcer resources over there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's talk about the Middle East for a moment in general and this particular customer. We have had a 50-year productive relationship with the Kingdom. And the vast preponderance of all of our combat programs are government-to-government, and the con
componenttext: Well, let's talk about the Middle East for a moment in general and this particular customer. We have had a 50-year productive relationship with the Kingdom. And the vast preponderance of all of our combat programs are government-to-government, and the contracts have been -- products have been fully vetted and supported, and this all happen to be products that the customer wants and needs. So we have seen no indication from the end-user customer that there is concern on their part or an intent on their part to change the profile of these -- of our deliveries. And look, we will -- we got these large advances, and we've been working those down, and then we'll continue to refresh cash flow as we -- from these customers as we increase deliveries. And so far, we're in pretty good shape.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could just ask one more, Phebe, maybe for Jason, but a follow-up to Doug's question. On this design release on Columbia, on Ohio replacement that's upcoming, could -- if the timing is there and the CR doesn't get in the way, could that be an in
componenttext: Okay. If I could just ask one more, Phebe, maybe for Jason, but a follow-up to Doug's question. On this design release on Columbia, on Ohio replacement that's upcoming, could -- if the timing is there and the CR doesn't get in the way, could that be an inflow of about $700-plus million of design money to you by the end -- before the end of the year or maybe early next year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, we will work with the Navy. I haven't planned on and haven't looked at the specific timing of the cash flow with respect to that order -- that contract because we don't have the contracts signed yet. So as soon as we get that contract, we'll have re
componenttext: Look, we will work with the Navy. I haven't planned on and haven't looked at the specific timing of the cash flow with respect to that order -- that contract because we don't have the contracts signed yet. So as soon as we get that contract, we'll have real clarity about the timing quarter-by-quarter of when we can expect the cash associated with that. But there's no way to estimate at the moment until that contract is signed.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. The reason I asked because it sounds like DoD could be making some kind of decision in early November.
componenttext: Right. The reason I asked because it sounds like DoD could be making some kind of decision in early November.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they are. They're making their Milestone B decision, which is predicated on that submission that we just made on the component -- detail design and component design. So that is a trigger. But once that decision is made, then you got to go to contrac
componenttext: Well, they are. They're making their Milestone B decision, which is predicated on that submission that we just made on the component -- detail design and component design. So that is a trigger. But once that decision is made, then you got to go to contract, right?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phebe, just a quick clarification. I want to make sure I heard you correctly. You said you got 50 orders on the 500?
componenttext: Phebe, just a quick clarification. I want to make sure I heard you correctly. You said you got 50 orders on the 500?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I said was that it's been my experience that you -- to have a successful launch of a new airplane, you need to have 50 orders before entry into service, and we are on our way to exceed that amount. So does that help?
componenttext: What I said was that it's been my experience that you -- to have a successful launch of a new airplane, you need to have 50 orders before entry into service, and we are on our way to exceed that amount. So does that help?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. And then looking out to 2018, you suggested that the 500 will contribute in that year and then meaningfully -- excuse me, in '17 and meaningfully in 2018. You've also suggested in the past that you've got some delivery slots that are availab
componenttext: Yes, it does. And then looking out to 2018, you suggested that the 500 will contribute in that year and then meaningfully -- excuse me, in '17 and meaningfully in 2018. You've also suggested in the past that you've got some delivery slots that are available on the 650 out there in the second quarter of 2018. I was wondering if you could update us on that. And what I'm trying to figure out here is whether you're going to have enough in the orders on the 650 to hold production flat out there in 2018 or if the plan here is to begin taking production rates down on that and having any hole from an EBIT perspective that gets created by the 650 decline and filled in by the 500. And that's kind of the key to the recipe of holding EBIT flat through these transitions.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, what we've said all along is that, to use that wonderful word, setter, we'll setter in additional 650s, but that production rate during the transition is not sustainable nor healthy and that we would never intend to keep that production rate
componenttext: Yes. So look, what we've said all along is that, to use that wonderful word, setter, we'll setter in additional 650s, but that production rate during the transition is not sustainable nor healthy and that we would never intend to keep that production rate up. What we aim for is to keep our backlog on 650s, on any of our programs but particularly that one, between 18 months and 2 years, and we're now at 2 years again. So as we think about that, I mean, that order book is there for -- we've got now 2 years next available. So that ought to give you a little bit of color on how we intend to think through as we set our deliveries and our delivery schedule. But I have not set and we haven't set until later in late November or mid-November our production schedule for next year. So on the fourth quarter call, I'll give you in copious details what we plan on doing. Okay?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
